of Trustees. The Chief of Police may suspend such license for ten (10) days
pending final action by the Board of Trustees. Any such suspension shall be
noted on the license, together with a statement of the reasons therefor, and
the driver shall be deprived of status by the officer suspending or revoking
such license. No driver whose license has been revoked shall again be licensed
as a taxicab driver in the Village, unless upon presentation of reasons
satisfactory to the Board of Trustees. (1976 Code § 36.33)
3-8-23-9: REVOCATION FOR DEFACING LICENSE:
Any holder of a taxicab driver's license who defaces, removes or obliterates
any official entry made upon his taxicab driver's license shall be punished by
the revocation of his license. (1976 Code § 36.34)
3-8-23-10: DRIVERS TO REPORT CHANGE OF RESIDENCE:
If any person licensed as a taxicab driver under this Chapter shall change his
residence at any time while his license is in force, he shall forthwith notify
the Chief of Police of such act. (1976 Code § 36.35)
3-8-23-11: RECORDS:
There shall be kept in the office of the Village Clerk and the Police
Department a complete record of each taxicab driver's license issued and of all
renewals, suspensions or revocations thereof. The Clerk's record shall be kept
on file with the original application of the driver for a license. (1976 Code §
36.36)
3-8-24: TAXIMETERS:
3-8-24-1: REQUIRED:
Each taxicab must have affixed thereto and in good working order a taximeter.
(1976 Code § 36.37)
3-8-24-2: PREREQUISITE TO TAXICAB LICENSE:
No taxicab license shall be issued for any taxicab until the taximeter attached
thereto shall have been inspected as provided by this Chapter and found to be
accurate. (1976 Code § 36.38)
3-8-24-3: APPROVAL:
No person shall drive a taxicab to which is attached a taximeter that has not
been duly inspected and approved. (1976 Code § 36.39)
3-8-24-4: OPERATION:
The dial of every taximeter with which every taxicab shall be equipped shall
show but one tariff. Such taximeter shall also properly and accurately
register, indicate and display the time consumed by the taxicab while in
waiting, the distance traveled and the amount of fare to be determined and
charged therefor. Each taximeter shall be equipped with a flag at least three
inches by two inches (3" x 2") in size, either painted red or bearing thereon
in letters at least one inch (1") in height, the word "Vacant" or the words
"For Hire". The flag post of such flag shall be kept up or toward a vertical
position when the taxicab is for hire and, when such taxicab is engaged in the
service of a passenger or passengers, such flag post shall be kept down or in a
horizontal position. (1976 Code § 36.40)
3-8-24-5: INSPECTIONS BY CHIEF OF POLICE:
Before any license shall be issued to a taxicab, it shall be the duty of the
Chief of Police to have examined, at the operator's expense, the taximeter
attached thereto, and report its condition to the Village Clerk. At least once
annually such inspection shall be performed and the meter sealed; provided,
however, that in the event complaint is made that any taximeter registers
improperly or inaccurately, it shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to
immediately have examined and inspected such taximeter. If such taximeter does
not comply with the requirements of the preceding section, then and in that
event it shall be unlawful for the owner or person in charge of such taxicab to
permit its use until such taxicab is equipped with a taximeter approved by the
Chief of Police. (1976 Code § 36.41)
3-8-24-6: PROCEDURE FOR TESTING; DEMAND TESTS:
Every taximeter shall be tested by running the taxicab to which it is attached
over a course of standard mile-in-length or by a mechanical test to prove the
accuracy of the register thereof. Either of the foregoing tests may be made at
the discretion of the Chief of Police.
In order to determine whether such taximeter correctly registers "waiting
time", it shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to test such taximeter by
comparing the time recorded as shown by the fare computed on the dial thereof
with the standard time. (1976 Code § 36.42)
It shall be the duty of any person owning, controlling or operating a taxicab
to deliver either the taxicab together with the taximeter, or the taximeter
detached therefrom, to the Chief of Police or any of his deputies, for the
purpose of making the aforesaid test upon demand; provided, however, such
person may, if desired, be present at the time such test is made. (1976 Code §
36.43)
3-8-24-7: TRANSFERRING METERS:
No person shall detach any certified or inspected taximeter from any taxicab
and attach the same to any other taxicab, the front wheels of which are of
different diameter from those with reference to which the taximeter was
originally tested, unless a new inspection or certification is had on such
taximeter. (1976 Code § 36.44)
3-8-24-8: SEALING TAXIMETERS AND RECORDS OF INSPECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to assure that all taximeters found
accurate and correct are sealed, and to keep a record of the number of each
taximeter and the date of the inspection thereof in the books of his office.
(1976 Code § 36.45)
3-8-24-9: VIEW OF TAXIMETER:
Each taxicab shall, during the period between sunset and sunrise, be equipped
with a light which shall be so reflected upon the dial of the taximeter as to
enable the passenger engaging and using such taxicab to read the figures
indicated thereon.
Every taximeter placed on a taxicab shall be so arranged that the dial thereof
is in plain view of the passenger while riding in such taxicab, or upon
alighting from the same. (1976 Code § 36.46)
3-8-24-10: FALSE SIGNALS:
No driver of a taxicab equipped with a taximeter, while carrying passengers or
under employment, shall display the signal affixed to such taximeter or other
similar device in such a position as to denote that he is employed at a rate of
fare different from that to which he is entitled under the provisions of this
Chapter. (1976 Code § 36.47)
3-8-25: RECIPROCITY:
Taxicab businesses, taxicabs and taxicab drivers licensed by reciprocating
communities, as set in Schedule B on file in the office of the Village Clerk
and made a part hereof by reference, are hereby exempted from the license and
fee provisions of this Chapter to the same extent that the ordinances of the
municipalities set forth in said Schedule B grant similar exemptions.
Said Schedule B may hereafter be amended from time to time by resolution of the
Board of Trustees.
Any violation by such foreign licensed taxicab business, taxicab or taxicab
driver shall be immediately reported to the licensing municipality for such
further action as may be deemed necessary by the corporate authorities of such
other municipality, and pursuant to the terms of its own taxicab ordinance.
The licensee hereunder violating the ordinance of a reciprocating municipality,
as set forth in Schedule B, shall be subject to the same penalties provided by
this Chapter as if such ordinance violation has taken place within the
corporate limits of the Village. (1976 Code § 36.48)
3-8-26: PENALTY:
Any licensee violating any provision of this Chapter shall, upon conviction, be
fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Conviction of a second violation during any
license period shall result in an automatic suspension of the pertinent license
for a period of thirty (30) days. The Board of Trustees, or any regularly
constituted board or commission appointed by the Board of Trustees, may, at a
public hearing during such thirty (30) day suspension period, permanently
revoke any license granted hereunder. The holding of such public hearing shall
be after not less than five (5) days' written notice to the licensee, and the
respondent in such hearing shall be afforded the opportunity to cross-examine
adverse witnesses and to present witnesses and evidence in his own behalf.
(1976 Code § 36.49)
CHAPTER 9
HOUSE AND GARAGE SALES
(Rep. by Ord. 38-92, 12-15-1992)
CHAPTER 10
SCAVENGERS
SECTION:
3-10-1: License Required; Fee
3-10-2: Application For License; Term
3-10-3: Bond Required; Conditions
3-10-4: Insurance Required
3-10-5: Vehicle Requirements
3-10-6: Disposal Of Refuse
3-10-7: Revocation Of License
3-10-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of scavenger, or
the collection or disposal of garbage or yard waste, without first having
secured a license therefor 1 .
The fee for such license shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) per year 2 .
(1976 Code § 14.07)
 
Notes
1 1. For provisions concerning garbage and refuse, see title 6, chapter 3 of
  this Code.
2 2. See also subsection
  3-1-7A of this title.
3-10-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; TERM:
Applications for such license shall be made to the Village Manager, and shall
be referred to the Village President and Board of Trustees. No such license
shall be issued except on order of the President and Board of Trustees.
No more than one such license shall be in force for the business of scavenger
or garbage and yard waste for the RS-1, RS-2, RS-3, RS-4, RS-5, RA-1, RM-1, RM-
2 and RM-3 Use Districts and living quarters in any other zoning district.
There shall be no limit on the number of licenses in other use districts.
Each license granted hereunder shall be for the term from January 1 until the
following December 31. Any applicant for a license must pay the annual fee
regardless of the time when the license is issued, and no refunds will be made
and no fees will be prorated. (Ord. 66-2011, 11-22-2011)
3-10-3: BOND REQUIRED; CONDITIONS:
No scavenger license shall be issued unless the applicant therefor shall first
file a performance bond with sureties to be approved by the Board of Trustees,
in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), with the Village as beneficiary
conditioned upon the licensee continuing to properly operate the business of
scavenger for the period covered by the license on the following terms: (1976
Code § 14.07)
   A.   For the one license in the Residential Districts including living
quarters in any other zoning district.
      1.   The licensee will have at least one vehicle in operation in
collecting garbage each week.
      2.   Collection will be made of all garbage and refuse properly placed in
suitable containers, complying within this chapter on the premises served;
provided, that the person so served is not delinquent in paying proper bills
rendered for such service.
      3.   The licensee will collect garbage and yard waste from each
residential unit in accordance with the contract between the licensee and the
Village.
      4.   The licensee will comply with all ordinance provisions relating to
the business and will properly dispose of all garbage and yard waste collected.
      5.   The fee for garbage and yard waste collection shall be established
by Village Board resolution.
      6.   Insurance requirements will be in accordance with the contract
between licensee and the Village.
   B.   For the use districts other than RS-1, RS-2, RS-3, RS-4, RS-5, RA-1,
RM-1, RM-2 and RM-3 and living quarters in any other zoning district,
collection of garbage shall be by private contract entered into between the
scavenger and the user of the scavenger service.
Yard waste service shall be obtained by private contract for residential units
greater than a six (6) flat and all other nonresidential zoned property. (1976
Code § 14.07; amd. Ord. 16-92, 5-19-1992)
3-10-4: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
No license shall be issued under this Chapter unless the applicant for such
license has first submitted proof of insurance in the form of a certificate of
insurance, naming the Village as an additional insured, issued by an insurer
duly authorized to issue such policies in the State. Such certificate shall
show the date of expiration of such insurance and shall certify that the same
shall not be cancelled without at least sixty (60) days' notice to the Village
Clerk. This policy shall be in accordance with the following:
   A.   Commercial General Liability: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00)
combined single limit per occurrence for bodily injury, personal injury and
property damage. The general aggregate shall be twice the required occurrence
limit. Minimum general aggregate shall be no less than two million dollars
($2,000,000.00).
   B.   Automobile Liability: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined
single limit per accident for bodily injury and property damage.
   C.   Worker's Compensation And Employer's Liability: Worker's compensation
limits as required by the Labor Code of the State of Illinois and employer's
liability limits of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). (Ord. 16-92, 5-19-
1992)
3-10-5: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
Any vehicle used by such scavenger in his business shall be watertight and
equipped with covers for such portions as are used for the transportation of
garbage or yard waste. It shall be unlawful for any such vehicle to be driven
on or through any street in the Village on Sunday for the purpose of garbage
collection. (Ord. 16-92, 5-19-1992)
3-10-6: DISPOSAL OF REFUSE:
It shall be unlawful for any scavenger to dispose of or store any refuse in any
place within the Village limits or within one mile thereof, excepting with the
permission of the Village President and Board of Trustees. (1976 Code § 14.07)
3-10-7: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The license granted can be revoked at any time by the Village if the service
rendered by the licensee is not satisfactory. If requested by the licensee, the
Village President and Board of Trustees will conduct a hearing on the quality
of services rendered, and if the licensee demonstrates the scavenger services
rendered were satisfactory, the revocation of its license will be rescinded.
(1976 Code § 14.07; amd. 1981 Code)
CHAPTER 11
BURGLAR AND HOLD-UP ALARM SYSTEMS
SECTION:
3-11-1: Title
3-11-2: Definitions
3-11-3: Digital Communicator Devices
3-11-3-1: Permit Required
3-11-3-2: Application For Permit By User; Fee
3-11-3-3: Application For Permit By Alarm Installers; Approval
3-11-3-4: Right Of Inspection
3-11-3-5: Restricted Numbers (Rep. by Ord. 12-84, 6-21-1984)
3-11-3-6: Contents Of Recorded Message (Rep. by Ord. 12-84, 6-21-1984)
3-11-3-7: Revocation Or Suspension Of Permit
3-11-3-8: Permit Fee
3-11-4: Signaling Devices
3-11-4-1: Monitoring System
3-11-4-2: Application For Permit By A Company Installer; Approval
3-11-4-3: Permit Required
3-11-4-4: Application For Permit By User
3-11-4-5: Right Of Inspection
3-11-4-6: Revocation Of Permit
3-11-4-7: Subscriber Charges
3-11-5: False Alarms
3-11-6: Identification Cards
3-11-7: Liability Of Village Limited
3-11-1: TITLE:
This Chapter shall be known as the BURGLAR AND HOLD-UP ALARM SYSTEMS ORDINANCE.
(Ord. 3-80, 2-6-1980)
3-11-2: DEFINITIONS:
ALARM EQUIPMENT INSTALLERS: Any person, firm or corporation that sells, leases
or installs alarm systems, automatic voice tape dialer devices or signaling
devices which transmit alarms upon receipt of a stimulus from a detection
apparatus to a bell or a remote monitoring location.
SIGNALING DEVICES: An electrically operated instrument which automatically
sends visual and audible signals over a signal line to be registered by
indicators at a monitor panel in a receiving terminal of the Police Department
and/or alarm companies receiving location. Signaling devices shall also include
such systems that provide visual and/or audible systems on the premises. (Ord.
3-80, 2-6-1980; amd. Ord. 12-84, 6-21-1984)
3-11-3: DIGITAL COMMUNICATOR DEVICES:
3-11-3-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall operate, maintain or install any automatic voice tape dialer
device to the Bensenville Police Department. All present automatic voice tape
dialer systems must be converted to digital communicator alarms by January 1,
1985 in order to be connected to the computer alarm board. Any new digital
communicator alarm system attached to the Police Department alarm board must
receive a permit as required by this Chapter. (Ord. 12-84, 6-21-1984)
3-11-3-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT BY USER; FEE:
Applications for permits to install, maintain and operate a digital
communicator device shall be filed with the Chief of Police on forms supplied
with an application fee of ten dollars ($10.00). Said application shall include
the following:
   A.   Name, address, telephone number and emergency telephone numbers of
alarm equipment user and type of business organization (individual,
partnership, corporation). If a partnership, names and addresses of the
partners; if a corporation, the names and addresses of the principal officers
and the state where incorporated.
   B.   A description of and operational specifications for the digital
communicator device or devices offered to the public, together with a statement
that the equipment does comply with the standards of Underwriter's
Laboratories, Factory Mutual, F.C.C., approval or equal. (Ord. 3-80, 2-6-1980;
amd. Ord. 12-84, 6-21-1984)
3-11-3-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT BY ALARM INSTALLERS; APPROVAL:
   A.   Application for permits to install, maintain and operate a digital
communicator device shall be filed with the Chief of Police on forms supplied.
Said application shall include the following:
      1.   Name, address and telephone number of alarm installer and type of
business organization (individual, partnership, corporation). If a partnership,
names and addresses of the principal officers and the state where incorporated.
      2.   A description of and operation specifications for the digital
communicator device or devices offered to the public, together with a statement
that the equipment does comply with the standards of Underwriter's
Laboratories, Factory Mutual, F.C.C., approval or equal.
      3.   A list of names and addresses of persons for whom installations have
been made by the applicant prior to the effective date hereof.
      4.   A list of criminal convictions, if any (other than for minor traffic
offenses) of the applicant, or a list of criminal convictions, if any (other
than for minor traffic offenses) of the partners, directors and officers, if
the applicant is other than an individual.
      5.   A statement of responsibility for service of the digital
communicator device that the applicant proposes for the public.
      6.   A statement that the applicant is willing to comply with other
reasonable rules and regulations about details of installation and operation of
such devices, as may be issued by the Chief of Police. (Ord. 3-80, 2-6-1980;
amd. Ord. 12-84, 6-21-1984)
   B.   The Chief of Police shall approve such application if he finds that:
(Ord. 3-80, 2-6-1980)
      1.   The digital communicator device is properly connected to the Keltron
Computer Board. (Ord. 12-84, 6-21-1984)
      2.   The alarm equipment installer installing the system maintains an
adequate service organization to repair, maintain and otherwise service the
digital communicator devices sold or leased by him.
The Chief of Police may impose reasonable conditions on the issuance and
exercise of said permit. (Ord. 3-80, 2-6-1980; amd. Ord. 12-84, 6-21-1984)
3-11-3-4: RIGHT OF INSPECTION:
The Chief of Police shall have the right to inspect any digital communicator
device on the premises where it is installed to be used both prior and
subsequent to the issuance of a permit, at a reasonable time, to determine
whether a permit should be granted or whether it is being used in conformity
with the terms of the permit and the provisions of this Chapter. (Ord. 3-80, 2-
6-1980; amd. Ord. 12-84, 6-21-1984)
3-11-3-5: RESTRICTED NUMBERS:
(Rep. by Ord. 12-84, 6-21-1984)
3-11-3-6: CONTENTS OF RECORDED MESSAGE:
(Rep. by Ord. 12-84, 6-21-1984)
3-11-3-7: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF PERMIT:
The Chief of Police may revoke or suspend any permit issued pursuant to the
provisions of this Chapter, after giving written notice to the permit holder
and an opportunity for the permit holder to effect compliance in ten (10) days
or less, if he determines that the digital communicator device under said
permit has been installed, maintained or operated in violation of the
provisions of this Chapter or of any term or condition of said permit or for
failure to pay any fee provided for in this Chapter. (Ord. 3-80, 2-6-1980; amd.
Ord. 12-84, 6-21-1984)
3-11-3-8: PERMIT FEE:
Each permit holder will pay a monthly fee, as charged by alarm company
contracting with the Village from time to time, for the privilege of being
connected to the alarm board at the Police Department's public safety building.
All such fees shall be paid directly to the alarm company providing alarm
equipment. (Ord. 12-84, 6-21-1984)
3-11-4: SIGNALING DEVICES:
3-11-4-1: MONITORING SYSTEM:
The Police Department is authorized to contract for the installation of a
uniform monitoring system to receive visual and audible signals over a signal
line or lines at a central location. This system shall have a capacity to meet
present needs and the ability to expand for future needs, and shall be
available to any subscriber who meets the requirements for a permit for
connection. (Ord. 3-80, 2-6-1980)
3-11-4-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT BY A COMPANY INSTALLER; APPROVAL:
   A.   Applications for permits to install, maintain and operate a signaling
device shall be filed with the Chief of Police on forms supplied. Said
application shall include the following:
      1.   Name, address and telephone number of alarm installer and type of
business organization (individual, partnership, corporation). If a partnership,
names and addresses of the partners; if a corporation, the names and addresses
of the principal officers and state where incorporated.
      2.   A description of and operation specifications for the signaling
devices offered to the public, together with a statement that the equipment
does comply with the standards of Underwriter's Laboratories, Factory Mutual,
or equal.
      3.   A list of names and addresses of persons for whom installations have
been made by the applicant prior to the effective date hereof.
      4.   A list of criminal convictions, if any (other than for minor traffic
offenses), of the applicant, or a list of criminal convictions, if any (other
than for minor traffic offenses), of the partners, directors and officers if
the applicant is other than an individual.
      5.   A statement of responsibility for service of the signaling devices
that the applicant proposes for the public.
      6.   A statement that the applicant is willing to comply with other
reasonable rules and regulations about details of installation and operation of
such devices, as may be issued by the Chief of Police.
   B.   The Chief of Police shall approve such application if he finds that:
      1.   The alarm installer has complied with other reasonable
considerations as imposed by the Chief of Police.
      2.   The alarm installer maintains an adequate service organization to
repair, maintain and otherwise service the signaling devices sold or leased by
him. (Ord. 3-80, 2-6-1980)
3-11-4-3: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall install, operate or maintain signaling devices without first
obtaining a permit as required by this Chapter. (Ord. 3-80, 2-6-1980)
3-11-4-4: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT BY USER:
Application for permits to install, maintain and operate a signaling device
shall be filed with the Chief of Police on forms supplied, with an application
fee of ten dollars ($10.00). Said application shall include the following:
name, address, telephone number and emergency telephone numbers of alarm user
and type of business organization (individual, partnership, corporation). If a
partnership, names and addresses of the partners; if a corporation, the names
and addresses of the principal officers and the state where incorporated. (Ord.
3-80, 2-6-1980)
3-11-4-5: RIGHT OF INSPECTION:
The Chief of Police shall have the right to inspect any signaling device on the
premises where it is intended to be used both prior to and subsequent to the
issuance of a permit at reasonable times, to determine whether a permit should
be granted and whether it is being used in conformity with the terms of the
permit and the provisions of this Chapter. (Ord. 3-80, 2-6-1980)
3-11-4-6: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
The Chief of Police may revoke or suspend any permit issued pursuant to the
provisions of this Chapter, giving written notice to the permit holder and an
opportunity for the permit holder to effect compliance within ten (10) days or
less, if he determines that the signaling device under said permit has been
installed, maintained or operated in violation of the provisions of this
Chapter or of any term or condition of said permit. (Ord. 3-80, 2-6-1980)
3-11-4-7: SUBSCRIBER CHARGES:
The permit holder shall pay the alarm equipment installer for all equipment at
their location and connection fees to the monitoring system and maintenance
charges necessitated by the installation, operation and maintenance of the
signaling devices in the monitoring system. The company supplying and
maintaining the monitoring system shall have the right to charge subscribers or
their alarm equipment installer a reasonable fee for connection to and
maintenance of the system. (Ord. 3-80, 2-6-1980)
3-11-5: FALSE ALARMS:
Each person holding a user permit for the operation or maintenance of an
automatic voice tape dialer or signaling device shall be responsible for any
false alarm transmitted by the device which they operate. The Chief of Police
shall maintain a record of all false alarms so transmitted, and pursuant to the
required notice and opportunity to be heard, may revoke or suspend the permit
for the operation of an automatic voice tape dialer device or signaling device
involved in the transmission of four (4) false alarms in any one year or may
make reasonable charges therefor. (Ord. 19-93, 5-4-1993)
   A.   Charges: The Village shall assess fines according to the following fine
schedule:
      5th through 8th false alarm   $100.00 per false alarm
      9th through 10th false alarm   150.00 per false alarm
      More than 10 false alarms   200.00 per false alarm
   All fines must be paid to the Director of Management Services within thirty
(30) days from the date of the invoice requesting payment of the fine(s).
      1.   Informal Hearing: Each alarm user shall be entitled to an informal
hearing with the Chief of Police or his designee for each false alarm in excess
of four (4). At the informal hearing, the subscriber may offer evidence that
the alarm activation for which he/she is charged was not a false alarm.
Such informal hearing must be requested in writing by certified mail, directed
to the Chief of Police, seven (7) days after the mailing of the invoice
requesting payment of the fine(s).
      2.   Billing Program: The documents containing the false alarm
information will be transmitted by the Police Department to the Director of
Management Services who will cause an invoice to be mailed to the alarm user
after four (4) false alarms have been registered in any one year. (Ord. 40-99,
7-6-1999)
   B.   Exception: No charge shall be imposed for false alarms for thirty (30)
days from date of installation and/or date of major alterations and additions,
nor shall a charge be made for false alarms activated by weather-related
conditions, telephone line interruptions or acts of God. (Ord. 19-93, 5-4-1993)
3-11-6: IDENTIFICATION CARDS:
All employees or agents of the alarm equipment installer shall be supplied with
a proper identification card. This ID card shall be in his possession at all
times and shall include photo, physical description and signature by an officer
of the employing company. (Ord. 3-80, 2-6-1980)
3-11-7: LIABILITY OF VILLAGE LIMITED:
The Village shall take every reasonable precaution to assure that alarm signals
and prerecorded alarm messages received by the Village are given appropriate
attention and are acted upon with dispatch. Nevertheless, the Village shall not
be liable for any defects in operation of automatic voice tape dialer devices
and signal device systems, for any failure or neglect of any person in
connection with the installation and operation of equipment, the transmission
of alarm signals and prerecorded alarm messages or the relaying of such signals
and messages. In the event that the Village finds it necessary to disconnect a
defective automatic voice tape dialer device or signaling device, the Village
shall incur no liability by such action. (Ord. 3-80, 2-6-1980)
CHAPTER 12
PRECIOUS STONES AND PRECIOUS METALS
SECTION:
3-12-1: Definitions
3-12-2: Registration Required
3-12-3: Availability Of Register
3-12-4: Reports To The Chief Of Police
3-12-5: Retention Of Articles
3-12-6: Purchase Or Exchange From Minors, Intoxicated Persons And Thieves
Prohibited
3-12-7: Penalties
3-12-1: DEFINITIONS:
MINOR: Any person under the age of eighteen (18).
ORIGINAL RETAILER: Any retailer who buys merchandise from a wholesaler and pays
Illinois sales tax upon such merchandise.
PRECIOUS METALS: Gold, silver and platinum.
PRECIOUS STONES: Diamonds, emeralds, jade, pearls, rubies and sapphires.
SEMI-PRECIOUS STONES: Amethyst, aquamarine, garnets, opals, peridots, topaz and
zirconia. (Ord. 25-82, 8-5-1982)
3-12-2: REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
It shall be the duty of all persons dealing in the purchase, sale or exchange
of jewelry, watches, precious stones and semi-precious stones, cutlery, coins,
precious metals, or any secondhand manufactured articles, composed wholly or in
part of precious metals, to keep a book in which every article received by them
in the course of their business, except for merchandise which has been
purchased from a wholesaler and a sales tax has been paid, shall be registered.
Such registration shall include as minute a description of every article as
possible, including the maker's name and number of every article so received.
The name, age, sex, residence, driver's license number, date and time of sale,
and general description of the person selling or exchanging articles shall be
taken and entered in the register. If the person selling or exchanging articles
shall not have a driver's license, he must, in lieu of a driver's license,
produce identification showing both the person's age and picture. These other
types of identification shall include, but not be limited to an identification
card issued by the Secretary of State, a passport, a voter's registration along
with a picture identification card, or a birth certificate along with a picture
identification card. The type of identification shall also be included in the
register. All entries in the book shall be made in ink. (Ord. 25-82, 8-5-1982)
3-12-3: AVAILABILITY OF REGISTER:
The register shall at all times be kept at the place of business of every
person engaging in the business as set forth in Section
3-12-2 of this Chapter. Members of the Police Department shall be allowed free
access to the register and the person shall give to such officers all
information in his possession concerning such articles and all persons selling
or exchanging the same. (Ord. 25-82, 8-5-1982)
3-12-4: REPORTS TO THE CHIEF OF POLICE:
All persons engaging in the business as set forth in Section
3-12-2 of this Chapter, shall furnish a weekly report to the Chief of Police at
his office. Such reports shall be due by twelve o'clock (12:00) noon every
Monday. The report shall cover all merchandise bought or exchanged during the
preceding week. The report shall show the name, age, sex, residence, driver's
license number and general description of each person who shall have sold or
exchanged any article during the preceding week, together with a full
description of the articles sold or exchanged by such person and the day and
the hour of the transaction. If a type of identification other than a driver's
license as described in Section
3-12-2 of this Chapter is used, that source should be documented in the report.
Every person engaging in such business shall keep duplicates of such reports in
a well-bound book or register, which book or register shall at all times be
subject to the inspection of members of the Police Department. (Any person
intending to engage in business as set forth in Section
3-12-2 who will not operate that business at an established and permanent
location shall give the Chief of Police at least 72 hours prior notice of the
location and date and hours of the operation of such business.) (Ord. 25-82, 8-
5-1982)
3-12-5: RETENTION OF ARTICLES:
All persons engaging in business as set forth in Section
3-12-2 of this Chapter shall retain any article received for a period of forty
eight (48) hours after the deadline for the weekly police report in which that
article was included. Articles included in the twelve o'clock (12:00) noon
police report on Monday shall not be resold, exchanged or otherwise disposed of
before twelve o'clock (12:00) noon on Wednesday of the same week. Articles must
be kept in the same state or condition in which they were received, and shall
not be comingled with other articles separately received and shall be made
available for examination by members of the Police Department during this
retention period. (Ord. 25-82, 8-5-1982)
3-12-6: PURCHASE OR EXCHANGE FROM MINORS, INTOXICATED PERSONS AND THIEVES
PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for anyone engaged in business as set forth in Section
3-12-2 of this Chapter to purchase from a minor or exchange with a minor any
articles regulated by Section
3-12-2. It shall be unlawful for anyone engaged in business as set forth in
Section
3-12-2 to purchase from or exchange with any person appearing to be intoxicated
or any person known to be a thief or to have been convicted of larceny, any
articles regulated by Section
3-12-2. (Ord. 25-82, 8-5-1982)
3-12-7: PENALTIES:
Any person found guilty of violating Sections
3-12-1 to
3-12-6 of this Chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Such person shall also be subject to
the revocation of any business license issued by the Village. (Ord. 25-82, 8-5-
1982)
CHAPTER 13
RAFFLES, AUCTIONS AND BLOCK PARTIES
SECTION:
3-13-1: Raffles, Definitions
3-13-2: Raffles, Permit Required
3-13-3: Raffles, Eligible Applicants
3-13-4: Raffles, Application
3-13-5: Raffles, Issuance Of License
3-13-6: Raffles, Conduct Of
3-13-7: Raffles Manager; Bond
3-13-8: Raffles, Records
3-13-9: Auctions, Definition
3-13-10: Auctions, Permit Required
3-13-11: Auctions, Application
3-13-12: Auctions, Issuance Of Permit
3-13-13: Block Parties, Definition
3-13-14: Block Parties, Permit Required
3-13-15: Block Parties, Application
3-13-16: Block Parties, Issuance Of Permit
3-13-17: Violations
3-13-1: RAFFLES, DEFINITIONS:
NET PROCEEDS: Gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less reasonable sums
expended for prizes, local license fees and other reasonable operating expenses
incurred as a result of operating a raffle.
RAFFLE: A form of "lottery," as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/28-
2 of the Criminal Code conducted by an organization licensed under this
Chapter, in which:
   A.   The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance,
represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of numbers or by
some other medium, one or more of which chances is to be designated the winning
chance;
   B.   The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing or by some
other method based on an element of chance by an act or set of acts on the part
of persons conducting or connected with the lottery, except that the winning
chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting
contest. (Ord. 36-82, 11-4-1982)
3-13-2: RAFFLES, PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct raffles or chances without having first obtained a
license therefor pursuant to this Chapter. (Ord. 36-82, 11-4-1982)
3-13-3: RAFFLES, ELIGIBLE APPLICANTS:
No license shall be issued except to bona fide religious, charitable, labor,
fraternal, educational, or veterans' organizations operating without benefit to
their members and existing continuously for a period of five (5) years
immediately before making application for license and having had, during that
entire five (5) year period of bona fide membership, engaged in carrying out
its purposes. (Ord. 36-82, 11-4-1982)
3-13-4: RAFFLES, APPLICATION:
Applications for licenses shall be submitted to the Village Clerk on
application forms provided by the Village. The application form shall specify:
   A.   The area or areas within the corporate limits of the Village in which
raffle chances will be sold or issued;
   B.   The time period during which raffle chances will be sold or issued;
   C.   The time of determination of winning chances and the location or
locations at which winning chances will be determined;
   D.   A sworn statement attesting to the nonprofit character of the
prospective licensee organization, signed by the presiding officer and
secretary, if any, of the organization. (Ord. 36-82, 11-4-1982)
3-13-5: RAFFLES, ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
Upon receipt of an application for license in proper form, and in all respects
complying with all sections of this Chapter, the Village Clerk shall issue a
license within thirty (30) days after the date of tender of the application.
Any licenses issued hereunder may be suspended or revoked by the Board of
Trustees upon five (5) days written notice to the licensee for any violations
of this Chapter, provided that no suspension or revocation shall occur without
opportunity for the licensee organization to appear before the Board of
Trustees for a hearing to show good cause why the license should not be
suspended or revoked. No license shall be issued to any organization ineligible
to receive the same under the provisions of 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 15/
3. (Ord. 36-82, 11-4-1982)
3-13-6: RAFFLES, CONDUCT OF:
The conduct of raffles is subject to the following restrictions:
   A.   The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to
the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that game.
   B.   No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization may
participate in the management or operation of the raffle.
   C.   No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in
the management or operation of the raffle.
   D.   A licensee may rent a premises on which to determine the winning chance
or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also licensed under
this Chapter.
   E.   Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the area specified on
the license and winning chances may be determined only at those locations
specified on the license.
   F.   No person under the age of eighteen (18) years may participate in the
conducting of raffles or chances. A person under the age of eighteen (18) years
may be within an area where winning chances are being determined only when
accompanied by his parent or guardian. (Ord. 36-82, 11-4-1982)
3-13-7: RAFFLES MANAGER; BOND:
All operation of and the conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of a
single raffles manager designated by the organization. The manager shall give a
fidelity bond in the sum of an amount determined by the Village in favor of the
organization conditioned upon his honesty in the performance of his duties.
Terms of the bond shall provide that notice shall be given in writing to the
Village not less than thirty (30) days prior to its cancellation. The Village
may waive this bond requirement by including a waiver provision in the license
issued to an organization, provided that a license containing such waiver
provision shall be granted only by unanimous vote of the members of the
licensed organization. (Ord. 36-82, 11-4-1982)
3-13-8: RAFFLES, RECORDS:
   A.   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep
records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single
gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All deductions
from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be documented
with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the
purchased item or service or other reason for the deduction, and the recipient.
The distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee, purpose, amount
and date of payment.
   B.   Gross receipts from the operation of raffles programs shall be
segregated from other revenues of the organization, including bingo gross
receipts, if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization
pursuant to license therefor issued by the Department of Revenue of the State
and placed in a separate account. Each organization shall have separate records
of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts, expenses and net
proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same person who
accounts for other revenues of the organization.
   C.   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall report promptly
after the conclusion of each raffle to its membership, and to the Village, its
gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from raffles, and the distribution of
net proceeds itemized as required in this Section.
   D.   Records required by this Section shall be preserved for three (3)
years, and organizations shall make available their records relating to
operation of raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and places.
(Ord. 36-82, 11-4-1982)
3-13-9: AUCTIONS, DEFINITION:
"Auction" shall mean a public sale in which property or items of merchandise
are sold to the highest bidder. (Ord. 51-94, 12-6-1994)
3-13-10: AUCTIONS, PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct an auction without having first obtained a permit
therefor pursuant to this Chapter. (Ord. 51-94, 12-6-1994)
3-13-11: AUCTIONS, APPLICATION:
Applications for permits shall be submitted to the Village Clerk on application
forms provided by the Village at least fourteen (14) days prior to the event.
The permit application fee shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00). The
application form shall specify:
   A.   Date, time and location of auction;
   B.   Name, address and telephone number of the party who ordered or arranged
the auction;
   C.   The relationship of this party to the property owner;
   D.   Name, address and telephone number of the party who will be conducting
the auction. (Ord. 51-94, 12-6-1994)
3-13-12: AUCTIONS, ISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
Upon receipt of an application for a permit in proper form, and in all respects
complying with all sections of this Chapter, the Village Clerk shall issue a
permit. Any permits issued hereunder may be suspended or revoked by the Board
of Trustees upon five (5) days written notice to the permittee for any
violations of this Chapter, provided that no suspension or revocation shall
occur without opportunity for the permittee's organization to appear before the
Board of Trustees for a hearing to show good cause why the permit should not be
suspended or revoked. No permit shall be issued to any organization ineligible
to receive the same under the provisions of 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 15/
3.
The permit shall be valid for one particular sale and premises designated
hereon and shall be posted so as to be easily seen by the public and shall be
nontransferable. The hours of the auction may be during the hours of eight
o'clock (8:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. (Ord. 51-94, 12-6-1994)
3-13-13: BLOCK PARTIES, DEFINITION:
"Block party" shall mean a social gathering that includes barricading a portion
of a public street for the purpose of the event. (Ord. 51-94, 12-6-1994)
3-13-14: BLOCK PARTIES, PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct a block party without having first obtained a license
therefor pursuant to this Chapter. (Ord. 51-94, 12-6-1994)
3-13-15: BLOCK PARTIES, APPLICATION:
Applications for permits shall be submitted to the Village Clerk on application
forms provided by the Village at least fourteen (14) days prior to the event.
The application form shall specify:
   A.   The names, addresses, telephone numbers and dates of birth of three (3)
persons over twenty one (21) who will take responsibility for sponsoring this
event;
   B.   The date, type and location of the event;
   C.   A rough sketch of the area, street and right of way affected by this
event;
   D.   Signature of one adult resident from one hundred percent (100%) of the
households whose residence abuts that portion of the public right of way to the
proposed event. The heading of this list should state, "My signature on this
paper gives my consent to hold the event listed on this application.";
   E.   If a stereo, amplifier device or band are to be used at the event, use
must be discontinued upon notification by the police to do so;
   F.   All sponsors must agree to abide by Village ordinances;
   G.   Fire trucks must have clearance;
   H.   There are to be no open fires;
   I.   No liquor is to be sold;
   J.   There shall be no games of chance or lotteries;
   K.   Sponsors' signatures must be notarized. (Ord. 51-94, 12-6-1994)
3-13-16: BLOCK PARTIES, ISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
Upon receipt of an application for a permit in proper form, and in all respects
complying with all sections of this Chapter, the Village Clerk shall issue a
permit. Any permits issued hereunder may be suspended or revoked by the Board
of Trustees upon five (5) days written notice to the permittee for any
violations of this Chapter, provided that no suspension or revocation shall
occur without opportunity for the permittee's organization to appear before the
Board of Trustees for a hearing to show good cause why the permit should not be
suspended or revoked. No permit shall be issued to any organization ineligible
to receive the same under the provisions of 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 15/
3.
The permit shall be valid for one particular event and premises designated
thereon and shall be nontransferable. (Ord. 51-94, 12-6-1994)
3-13-17: VIOLATIONS:
Any violation of any provision of this Chapter shall be subject, upon
conviction, to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. (Ord. 36-82, 11-4-1982)
CHAPTER 14
BENSENVILLE CABLE TELEVISION FRANCHISE
SECTION:
3-14-1: Title
3-14-2: Definitions
3-14-3: Grant Of Franchise
3-14-4: Jurisdiction Of Grant Of Franchise
3-14-5: Rates
3-14-6: Rate Payment
3-14-7: Franchise Fee
3-14-8: Records
3-14-9: General System Standards
3-14-10: Channels And Other Facilities
3-14-11: Use Of Municipal Streets
3-14-12: Business Office And Service Calls
3-14-13: Supervision Of The Company
3-14-14: Liability, Insurance And Indemnity
3-14-15: Surety Bond
3-14-16: Compliance With Local, State And Federal Jurisdiction
3-14-17: Establishment, Construction And Operation
3-14-18: Acceptance
3-14-19: Transfer Of Franchise
3-14-20: Revocation
3-14-21: Reservation Of Rights
3-14-22: Renewal
3-14-23: Termination Of Service
3-14-24: Construction
3-14-25: Notices
3-14-26: Exclusive Jurisdiction
3-14-1: TITLE:
This Chapter shall be known as and may be cited as the VILLAGE OF BENSENVILLE
CABLE TELEVISION FRANCHISE ORDINANCE. (Ord. 38-82, 11-18-1982)
3-14-2: DEFINITIONS:
The words and phrases defined in this Section shall have the meanings ascribed
to them as follows:
BASIC CABLE: All channels, and signals provided to subscribers from the system,
except premium programming, FM services, and special services such as help and
alarm systems, fire and burglar systems, etc.
CHANNEL: A frequency in the electromagnetic spectrum capable of clearly and
effectively carrying an audio-data or an audio-visual television signal, and as
defined by the FCC rules and regulations.
COMPANY: Continental Cablevision of Cook County, Inc. and its parent,
subsidiaries and affiliates.
CONVERTER: An electronic device which converts signals to a frequency not
susceptible to interference within a fully functional television receiver of a
subscriber and which permits a subscriber by an appropriate channel selector to
receive all signals referred to under this Chapter.
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The Village President and the Board of Trustees.
FCC: The Federal Communications Commission, established by the Communications
Act of 1934, as amended, and shall include any successor agency or other agency
with respect to the Federal regulation and licensing in connection with the
subject matter of this Chapter.
FM SERVICES: Transmission of audio signals only on a broad band standard FM
frequency.
GRANT: The right, privilege and franchise provided in subsection
 3-14-3A of this Chapter.
GROSS REVENUES: Shall include any and all compensation or receipts derived by
the grantee from the operation within the municipality of the cable television
system authorized herein, but shall not include any refunds or credits made to
subscribers or any taxes imposed on the services furnished by the grantee. It
shall include, but not be limited to, data transmission, alarm or signal
transmission, advertising revenue, charges to subscribers for basic cable,
premium programming, FM services, installation charges, and any and all revenue
received from any source whatsoever for use of the system facilities for the
transmission of electronic or microwave impulses.
MUNICIPALITY: The Village of Bensenville.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, partnership, limited partnership, association,
corporation, company, or organization of any kind.
POTENTIAL SUBSCRIBERS: Those persons within or without the current jurisdiction
of the grant or franchise who are not subscribers, who have refused system
services, or who have let lapse the time provided in subsection
3-14-5C of this Chapter, with due consideration given to the reasonable
probability that such persons may or may not become subscribers.
PREMIUM PROGRAMMING: Any commercial-free programming, including, but not
limited to, movies, concerts, variety acts, sporting events and the like for
which an additional charge is made.
PUBLIC RIGHT OF WAY: All sidewalks, streets and alleys in the municipality
which are dedicated to the municipality for street, highway, sidewalk,
lighting, drainage, utility, or cable television purposes, and all public ways
and places contiguous thereto.
SUBSCRIBER: Any person receiving service from or using the system under the
grant pursuant to this Chapter.
SYSTEM: Community antenna television system as defined in 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-42-11, and as amended from time to time.
SYSTEM FACILITIES: A system composed of, without limitation, antennas, cables,
wires, lines, towers, amplifiers, conductors, converters, equipment or
facilities, designed, constructed or wired for the purpose of producing,
receiving, amplifying, and distributing by coaxial cable, fiber optics,
microwave or other means, audio and/or visual radio, television, electronic or
electrical signals to and from subscribers and located within the municipality.
(Ord. 38-82, 11-18-1982)
3-14-3: GRANT OF FRANCHISE:
   A.   The municipality, to the full extent that it may do so, hereby grants
to the company, in accordance with the terms, conditions, and provisions of
this Chapter, the nonexclusive right, privilege and franchise: to establish,
construct, operate, and maintain the system and system facilities in, upon,
over, and under the public right of way and within easements or other rights to
use the property which are effective for the purposes of the grant; to extend
the system and to offer the services of the system to all potential subscribers
within the municipality; to acquire by lease, license, purchase or other right
to use equipment, facilities, and improvements, and land constituting all or
part of the systems facilities; to connect subscribers to the system; and to
repair, replace, enlarge, and extend the system and system facilities.
   B.   The term of the grant shall be fifteen (15) years. (Ord. 38-82, 11-18-
1982)
3-14-4: JURISDICTION OF GRANT OF FRANCHISE:
   A.   The grant shall apply within the corporate limits of the municipality,
including all territory hereafter annexed to the municipality.
   B.   The company shall be required to extend the system to and to offer the
services of the system to potential subscribers within all areas of the
municipality.
   C.   Notwithstanding the grant, the company shall obtain all necessary
Federal, State, and local government permits, licenses, and other required
authorizations in connection with the establishment, construction, operation,
and maintenance of the system and system facilities.
   D.   If an intergovernmental agreement or contact is made by and between the
municipality and the County of DuPage in connection with the extension of the
system and the offer of the services of the system to potential subscribers in
areas outside of the municipality's corporate limits, the company may so extend
the system and offer services to potential subscribers within such areas,
unless area is served by another company. If the city of Wood Dale enters into
a contract with a cable television company awarding a cable television
franchise for subscribers within the corporate limits of the city of Wood Dale,
the company agrees to enter into agreements with the cable television company
awarded the city of Wood Dale franchise to provide mutual access to subscribers
in both municipalities for public access programs originating in both the
municipality and Wood Dale. (Ord. 38-82, 11-18-1982)
3-14-5: RATES:
   A.   The municipality hereby accepts the company's proposal of rates and
services and supplements thereto which are adopted by reference and on file in
the office of the Village Clerk. The company hereby agrees that the rates
contained in said Exhibit "1" which is on file in the office of the Village
Clerk will not be increased during a period of two (2) years after the system
is operational and cable television service is first offered to the residents
of the municipality. The system shall be deemed operational when seventy five
percent (75%) of street miles of cable have been installed in the municipality
and the system is able to provide audio and visual signals to subscribers.
   B.   The rates for all programming and services shall be nondiscriminatory
provided that nothing contained herein shall be deemed to prohibit reasonable
promotional rates which may, from time to time, be less than the standard rates
imposed, and the company shall be allowed to establish a reduced rate for
multiple occupancy structures, but no consumer shall pay more than the rates
set forth in Exhibit "1" adopted by reference and on file in the office of the
Village Clerk.
   C.   There shall be no charge for the connection or installation of basic
cable service or premium programming if ordered at one time within six (6)
months of the availability to an individual subscriber as determined by the
dated offer from the company to the individual subscriber. Any order for
installation submitted to the company during said six (6) month period shall be
performed without charge notwithstanding the actual date of installation. If an
individual subscriber shall not order installation within the said six (6)
month period, the company shall have the right to charge the installation fees
set on Exhibit "1" adopted by reference and on file in the office of the
Village Clerk.
   D.   After the initial period provided in subsection A hereof, the company
may, without approval of the municipality, increase its rates for subscriber
services not more than once in any calendar year by such percentage as does not
exceed the increase in the U.S. Department of Labor Consumer Price Index
(C.P.I) for Chicago, Illinois, such increases to be cumulative. Further,
following the rate freeze noted above, the company may also adjust its rates so
as to reflect any changes in copyright fees paid at the direction of the
Federal Communications Commission Copyright Tribunal subsequent to the passage
of this Chapter. The company shall notify the municipality and all subscribers
at least ninety (90) days in advance of any such increase.
If any proposed increase exceeds the limitation set forth above, prior
municipal approval thereof shall be required and no such rate increase shall
become effective until such municipal approval.
   E.   Charges shall abate prorata in the event that service to a subscriber
is interrupted for more than twenty four (24) hours for any reason whatsoever
except for damage caused by the subscriber. (Ord. 38-82, 11-18-1982)
3-14-6: RATE PAYMENT:
   A.   Unless the company provides a longer time, subscribers shall pay
connection charges to the company at the time the installation is made
(subject, however, to the provisions of subsection
3-14-5C of this franchise).
   B.   Unless the company provides a longer time, subscribers shall pay
monthly in advance for systems services on or before the first day of the month
in which company is to provide services. (Ord. 38-82, 11-18-1982)
3-14-7: FRANCHISE FEE:
   A.   The company shall pay to the municipality for the right, privilege, and
franchise in connection with the grant, an amount equal to five percent (5%) of
the gross revenues per annum. Payment shall be semi-annual within thirty (30)
days following June 30 and December 31. Each payment shall be accompanied by a
statement under oath from an official or representative of the company having
the requisite knowledge to make such a statement certifying the gross revenues
upon which payment is based.
   B.   Delinquent payments shall bear interest at the rate of one percent (1%)
per month with the minimum delinquency being a one month interest charge.
   C.   Within ninety (90) days of the end of each fiscal year of the company,
the company shall file with the corporate authorities an annual report
prepared, certified, and audited by the company's auditors, showing the
financial status of the company and total revenues of the company from the
system for the report period.
   D.   Upon termination of the grant either at the expiration of its terms or
otherwise, the company shall continue to make semi-annual statements and
certifications and the annual report as provided in this Section until such
time as all payments of the municipality under this Chapter have been paid and
accounted for to the reasonable satisfaction of the municipality.
   E.   In the event the company grants a franchise fee in excess of five
percent (5%) to any other municipality within Cook and/or DuPage Counties
(exclusive of the City of Chicago), under the same terms and conditions, the
franchise fee payable hereunder shall be increased to a like amount.
The change in the percentage of franchise fee shall go into effect on the
effective date of the ordinance in the other municipality where the company
operates granting a franchise fee higher than five percent (5%).
To facilitate the implementation of this Section, the company shall, within
fifteen (15) days after their passage, send to the municipality notice of all
ordinances granting them a franchise within Cook or DuPage Counties, (exclusive
of the City of Chicago). (Ord. 38-82, 11-18-1982)
3-14-8: RECORDS:
   A.   All financial records of the company in connection with its activities
within the boundaries of the municipality shall be maintained in a manner which
permits distinguishing revenues earned within a municipality from revenues
earned by the company in other municipalities.
   B.   The municipality shall have the right, upon reasonable notice to the
company and at reasonable times, hours, dates and frequencies, to inspect all
or any part of the company's records and documents, planning records and
documents, and engineering records and documents of every kind in connection
with the grant, the system, the system facilities, and the company's
undertakings with respect to this Chapter.
   C.   The company shall simultaneously file with the municipality a copy of
all petitions and applications filed or submitted by the company with any
governmental entity or agency having jurisdiction with respect to any matter
affecting the system, system facilities, or the company's undertakings with
respect to this Chapter.
   D.   At least ten (10) days prior to construction of any part of the system
or system facilities in public right of way, the company shall file with the
municipality copies of maps, plats, or other drawings which accurately show the
nature of the proposed construction or improvements. Such copies shall show all
existing public or private improvements. Upon completion of such construction,
the company shall submit "as built" plans which also show existing public or
private improvements.
   E.   The company shall file annually with the municipality a current list of
its owners, partners, both general and limited, and officers, together with a
list of shareholders having two percent (2%) or more of the stock if the
company is a corporation.
   F.   The company shall supply the municipality copies of all rules,
regulations, terms, and conditions established or imposed by the company in
connection with the establishment, construction, operation, and maintenance of
the system upon demand of the municipality. (Ord. 38-82, 11-18-1982)
3-14-9: GENERAL SYSTEM STANDARDS:
   A.   The company shall establish and construct the system in accordance with
the highest standards of the art of cable communications in existence at the
commencement of construction and in accordance with the highest standards of
code of conduct with respect to businesses of size and type like that of the
company.
   B.   The company through the system shall provide effective and efficient
service in accordance with the rules and regulations of all governmental units
and agencies having regulatory and licensing authority in connection with the
system.
   C.   The company shall cause to be delivered to the subscribers' homes
signals that meet FCC technical standards.
   D.   The company shall not unreasonably interrupt all or part of the
services of the system except under emergency circumstances or circumstances
beyond the company's control or without approval of the Village Manager.
Interruption of services on the system for routine maintenance shall be
confined to the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. to seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
and not otherwise.
   E.   The company shall establish, construct, operate and maintain the
system, including system facilities, so as to at all times meet FCC technical
standards, including, without limitation, specifications for frequency
boundaries, visual carriers, frequency levels, aural carrier frequency levels,
channel frequency response, terminal isolation and radiation.
   F.   The company shall establish, construct, operate and maintain the system
in accordance with all applicable national, State, and local building and
safety codes. In the absence of any otherwise applicable building and safety
codes, the company shall establish, construct, operate and maintain the system
in accordance with the most recent edition of the National Electrical Safety
Code and the National Electrical Code.
   G.   Without limiting the provisions of this Chapter, the company, at a
minimum, shall establish, construct, operate and maintain the system in
accordance with written proposals or representations made to the corporate
authorities. A copy of the company's proposal to the municipality has been
filed with the Clerk of the municipality and is by this reference incorporated
herein.
   H.   The system shall be designed, established, constructed, operated and
maintained for twenty four (24) hour-a-day continuous operation.
   I.   The system shall produce for receipt on subscriber's receivers, which
are in good working order, either monochrome or color pictures (providing the
receiver is color capable) that are free from any significant interference,
distortion or ghosting which would cause any material degradation of video or
audio quality.
   J.   The system shall be capable of providing emergency override alerts
whereby the municipality or other governmental units or agencies designated by
the municipality may be able to issue a bulletin on all channels
simultaneously.
   K.   In connection with the system the company shall utilize personnel with
necessary and sufficient skills and experience or training as such shall relate
to their respective jobs and positions.
   L.   The company shall not be liable for interruption in service caused by
strikes, war, civil commotion, acts of God and other causes beyond the control
of the company.
   M.   The company shall be prohibited from the showing of X-rated films or
programs. (Ord. 38-82, 11-18-1982)
3-14-10: CHANNELS AND OTHER FACILITIES:
   A.   The system shall have a minimum capacity of four hundred (400)
megahertz.
   B.   The system shall have a broad band FM signal.
   C.   The system shall provide for, or shall be capable of, receiving and
transmitting all VHF, UHF, and FM signals. UHF stations carried on the system
shall be converted to cable channels.
   D.   The system shall carry all available local television stations as
presently required by the FCC.
   E.   The system shall carry at least one channel for each of the following
purposes:
      1.   Municipal access.
      2.   Educational access.
      3.   Public access.
   F.   Other available channels will be made available for municipal,
educational and public access when demand requires, to a maximum of nine (9)
channels, following the initial activation of the three (3) channels noted in
subsection E of this Section.
   G.   The system shall provide, in addition to the carriage of television
signals, auxiliary services, premium programming, two (2) way services, when
technically available.
   H.   The system shall provide without cost an institutional loop connecting
all designated public buildings of the municipality, and all designated public
buildings of the school districts serving the residents of the municipality,
the Bensenville Park District and the Bensenville Public Library, where such
buildings are within the corporate limits of the Village. All such facilities
shall be equipped for program origination as well as the receipt of television
signals at no additional cost to the municipality or other public bodies.
   I.   The system shall provide access to the company's existing studio
located in Elmhurst, Illinois for local programming on an equal basis with
Elmhurst and any other municipalities. The studio shall be available at no cost
on a time-sharing basis to the municipality, schools, the Bensenville Library,
the Bensenville Park District and other public service or civic organizations
within the municipality. The studio shall be maintained with modern equipment
required to meet the Village's programming needs in cable television
transmission. The company will provide at no cost trained personnel to assist
and educate residents of the municipality in the transmission of municipal,
educational or public access programs. If the company's existing studio in
Elmhurst, Illinois becomes unable to provide access to institutions or
residents of the municipality on a timely or efficient basis, the company
agrees to expand its studio facilities or construct an additional studio within
the corporate limits of the municipality to meet the municipal, educational or
public access needs of the municipality.
   J.   The system will provide mobile van unit(s) and other remote program
origination facilities adequate to meet the demand from the municipality and
other public bodies for the origination of programs outside the company's
studio. The remote program origination facilities will be staffed with trained
personnel. The company's personnel will, upon request, train authorized
students from the municipality's school districts in the operation and
maintenance of remote program facilities. Such equipment and services shall be
provided without cost to the municipality or any other public bodies.
   K.   The system shall furnish at cost electronic surveillance equipment for
buildings owned by the municipality, the school districts, park district and
public library. (Ord. 38-82, 11-18-1982)
3-14-11: USE OF MUNICIPAL STREETS:
   A.   All system facilities erected, constructed or placed by the company
within the municipality shall be located so as not to interfere with the proper
use of streets, alleys and other public ways and places, and to cause minimum
interference with the rights or reasonable convenience of property owners to
adjoin any of the said streets, alleys or other public ways and places, and not
to interfere with existing public utility installations. All service lines
shall be underground in those areas of the municipality where both public
utilities providing telephone or electric service are underground at the time
of installation. In areas where telephone or electric utility facilities are
aboveground at the time of installation, the company may install its service
aboveground. If, subsequently, the telephone or electric utility facilities go
underground, the affected facilities of the company shall go underground
simultaneously.
   B.   In case of any disturbance of pavement, sidewalk, driveway or other
surfacing, the company shall, at its own expense, and in the manner required by
the municipal ordinances or policies, replace and restore all paving, sidewalk,
driveway or other surface of any street or alley disturbed. In case of any
disturbance on either private or public property, the land surface, including
plantings and trees, shall be restored by the company to substantially its
previous condition.
   C.   If at any time during the period of the franchise the municipality
shall lawfully elect to alter, or change the grade or location of any street,
alley or other public way, the company shall, upon reasonable notice by the
municipality, remove, relay and relocate affected system facilities at its own
expense, and in each instance comply with the requirement of the municipality.
   D.   The company shall not place system facilities above or below ground
where the same will cause service interruption with any gas, electric,
telephone fixtures, water hydrants or other utility, and all such pole,
conduits or other fixtures placed in any street shall be so placed as to comply
with all ordinances of the municipality.
   E.   The company may be required by the municipality to permit joint use of
its system facilities located in the streets, alleys, or other public right of
way of the municipality by utilities insofar as such joint use may be
reasonably practicable and upon payment of reasonable rental thereof, such
rental fees to be equivalent to those paid to said utilities by the company.
   F.   The company shall, on request of any person holding a moving permit
issued by the municipality, temporarily move affected system facilities to
permit the moving of buildings, the expense of such temporary removal to be
paid by the person requesting such removal in advance, and the company shall be
given not less than forty eight (48) hours' advance notice to arrange for such
temporary changes.
   G.   The company shall have the authority, except when in conflict with
existing municipal ordinances, to trim any trees upon and overhanging public
right of way so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact
with system facilities.
   H.   The municipality shall have the right to install and maintain free of
charge upon the property of the company its own equipment, including, but not
limited to, a police and fire system and emergency services disaster agency as
the municipality requires, at its own expense, on the condition that such
equipment does not unreasonably interfere with the company's establishment,
construction, operation and maintenance of the system.
   I.   If the company seeks to construct and maintain its cables and other
system facilities on or above public or private property, and an easement for
such use has already been granted to a telephone company, electric or other
public utility, said easement shall, if at all possible, be interpreted so as
to grant the company the same rights and privileges as have been granted to the
telephone and electric companies and other public utilities. In such easements,
the words "telephone" or "telephone company", "electric company" and the like,
shall be interpreted to include the company. The company shall not be required
to install cable to service areas where the required easements are not
reasonably obtainable. (Ord. 38-82, 11-18-1982)
3-14-12: BUSINESS OFFICE AND SERVICE CALLS:
   A.   The company shall establish, operate and maintain within Bensenville a
business office and agent for the purpose of receiving inquiries, requests and
complaints concerning all aspects of the establishment, construction,
maintenance and operation of the system and the payment of subscriber's service
charges, upon the direction of the Village. The office shall have a listed
telephone and shall be open during reasonable business hours.
   B.   The company shall respond to and resolve subscribers' complaints or
requests for service in connection with repairs and maintenance and
malfunctions of system facilities. The company shall respond as soon as
possible on such complaints or requests, but not more than twenty four (24)
hours after receipt of the complaint.
   C.   The company shall file with the municipality copies of all of its rules
and regulations in connection with the handling of inquiries, requests and
complaints. The company shall in writing furnish to subscribers at the time
they connect to the system information concerning procedures for making
inquiries, requests and complaints about the system. The information shall at
least include the address and telephone number of the business office and
agent. The company shall provide such information as will reasonably permit
subscribers to effectively submit inquiries, requests and complaints and to
obtain satisfactory resolution or handling in connection therewith, especially
in connection with the quality of the company's delivery of services.
   D.   The company shall keep full records in connection with all inquiries,
complaints and requests in connection with the system. Such records shall at
least identify the person in contact, the subject matter of the contact and the
resolution of the matter in question or the action taken by the company in
connection with the contact. (Ord. 38-82, 11-18-1982)
3-14-13: SUPERVISION OF THE COMPANY:
   A.   Unless specifically otherwise provided in this Chapter, or unless the
corporate authorities shall otherwise specify, all administrative actions
required to be taken or which shall or may be taken by the municipality in
connection with the system, shall be taken by the Village Manager or such other
person designated by the Village Manager.
   B.   Unless specifically otherwise provided in this Chapter, or unless the
corporate authorities shall otherwise provide, all filings with the
municipality required by this Chapter shall be made with the Village Clerk.
(Ord. 38-82, 11-18-1982)
3-14-14: LIABILITY, INSURANCE AND INDEMNITY:
   A.   The company hereby agrees to indemnify, defend and save whole and
harmless the municipality and its officers and employees from liabilities and
related expenses (including reasonable attorney fees) of any kind which may
arise out of or from the establishment, construction, operation and maintenance
of the system or system facilities or the execution and implementation of this
Chapter. The municipality shall notify the company in the event any person
shall in any way notify the municipality of any claim or demand in connection
with the system, the system facilities or this Chapter from which the company
may be subject to liability under this Section or otherwise and the Village
will tender defense of claim to the company. The undertaking in connection with
subsection A in this Section includes liabilities or claims of liability in
respect to property damage, personal injury, invasions of the right of privacy,
defamation of any person, the violation or infringement of any copyright,
trademark, trade name, service mark or patent, or of any other right of any
person, and failure of the company to comply with the provisions of any
Federal, State or local statute, ordinance, rule or regulation applicable to
the company in connection with this Chapter.
   B.   The company shall keep the system and system facilities continuously
insured against such risks as are customarily insured against by businesses of
like size and type, including, but not limited to:
      1.   Insurance to the extent of two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) per
occurrence against liability for bodily injury including death and to the
extent of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per occurrence against
liability for damage to property including loss of use, occurring on, arising
out of, or in any way related to the system or system facilities.
      2.   During any period of construction, adequate coverage to meet
liability under the Illinois Structural Work Act.
      3.   Workman's compensation insurance with statutory limits and
employer's liability insurance of not less than one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000.00).
      4.   Comprehensive automobile liability insurance to the extent of one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence against liability for bodily
injury including death and to the extent of three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000.00) per occurrence against liability for damage to property including
loss of use occurring on, arising out of, or in any way related to the system.
This subsection shall not be limited on the company's undertaking provided in
subsection A of this Section.
   C.   The company shall have the municipality and all of its officers and
employees included as co-insured on all insurance policies referred to in this
Section. The company shall file with the municipality copies of all such
policies. All such policies shall provide that the issuing insurance company
will not cancel them without ten (10) days' prior notice to the company and the
municipality. All such policies shall be taken out and maintained with
generally recognized responsible insurance companies qualified to do business
in the State and carrying a rating of A + AAAAA in the most recent publication
of Best's Insurance Guide. (Ord. 38-82, 11-18-1982)
3-14-15: SURETY BOND:
   A.   The company shall maintain throughout construction and for one year
after completion of the facilities to be provided under this Chapter, a letter
of credit in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00)
conditioned on the company fulfilling and performing in connection with each
provision, term and condition of this Chapter, and that in case of any breach,
the municipality shall be entitled to recover on said letter of credit in the
amount of any damages, and all costs and attorney fees incurred by the
municipality, proximately resulting from the failure of the company to well and
faithfully observe and perform under any and all of the provisions, terms and
conditions which this Chapter requires it to perform. Letter of credit to be
approved by attorney for the municipality.
   B.   No recovery by the municipality of any sum by reason of the letter of
credit required by this Section shall be any limitation upon the liability of
the company to the municipality, except that any sum received by the
municipality by reason of said letter of credit shall be deducted from any
recovery which the municipality might have against the company.
