6-2-3: LITTERING PUBLIC PLACES 1 :
It is unlawful for any person to deposit, place, leave or dump any refuse,
rubbish, junk, trash or waste material of any kind in or upon any street,
sidewalk, alley, sewer, parkway, park or other public place in the village. For
the purpose of this section vehicles or parts of vehicles not in condition for
normal use shall be considered as junk or trash. (1976 Code § 12.06)
 
Notes
1 2. See also section
  6-3-6 of this title.
6-2-4: INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES:
   A.   "Inoperable motor vehicle" means any motor vehicle from which, for a
period of at least seven (7) days, the engine, wheels or other parts have been
removed or on which the engine, wheels or other parts have been altered,
damaged or otherwise so treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven
under its own motor power.
"Inoperable motor vehicle" shall not include a motor vehicle which has been
rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own motor power in
order to perform ordinary service or repair operations.
   B.   An "inoperable motor vehicle", as defined herein, whether on public or
private property, and in view of the general public, is hereby declared to be a
nuisance. Nothing in this section shall apply to any motor vehicle that is kept
within a building when not in use, to historic vehicles over twenty five (25)
years of age, or to a motor vehicle on the premises of a place of business
engaged in the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles. (Ord. 5-84, 2-16-1984)
   C.   The chief code enforcement officer shall notify in writing any person
maintaining or controlling an inoperable motor vehicle in violation of this
section. Said notice shall require said person to cease and desist said
violation within forty eight (48) hours after the date of said notice. Any
person who violates, disobeys, or refuses to comply with said notice within
forty eight (48) hours after the date of said notice shall be fined not less
than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
Each day that such persons fails to dispose of the inoperable motor vehicle in
violation of said notice shall be deemed to be a separate offense. (Ord. 5-84,
2-16-1984; amd. Ord. 44-98, 7-21-1998)
   D.   The keeping and maintaining of an "inoperable motor vehicle" as defined
herein shall also be subject to abatement in the manner provided in this
chapter for the abatement of public nuisances. (Ord. 5-84, 2-16-1984)
6-2-5: NO SMOKING IN RETAIL FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS:
A "retail food establishment" is hereby defined as an establishment that keeps
for sale, sells, or offers for sale, at retail, any cooked or uncooked meats,
agricultural products, drinks, confections, condiments, or any other material
or articles used as food for human consumption, where the same are not served
for consumption on the premises. It is hereby found that smoking in retail food
establishments is detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare. It is
unlawful for any person to carry or smoke a lighted cigarette, cigar or pipe in
any retail food establishment, or within fifteen feet (15') of the entrance of
any retail food establishment. Any person who violates this section shall be
fined less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) for each offense. (Ord. 52-2009,
8-25-2009)
6-2-6: INSECT AND RODENT CONTROL:
   A.   All structures and properties shall be kept free from insect
infestation and rodent infestations. All garbage, debris and refuse shall be so
stored in a garbage can and/or dumpster free of holes with lids completely
closed as not to invite insects or rodents or be unsightly or a nuisance.
Exterior storage of items not manufactured and intended for outdoor
recreational yard use are not permitted. Acceptable items are items such as
patio furniture, grill, and play yard equipment. All non-conforming items must
be stored inside an enclosed structure or removed.
   B.   All structures and/or properties in which insect infestation or rodent
harborage is found or suspected shall be promptly exterminated at the property
owner's expense by a village-approved rodent abatement/control company.
   C.   All residential rental properties and multi-family properties,
including, but not limited to, condominiums, apartments, and modular or
manufactured housing, shall be treated not less than on a monthly basis by a
licensed rodent control company. Activity result reports and/or receipts shall
be made available to the village upon request of a village inspector. If, upon
inspection of any residential property, there is found or suspected to be
insect and/or rodent infestation in more than one (1) dwelling unit, the
landlord/owner shall contract with a licensed rodent control company to treat
all common areas and infested dwelling units on no less than a monthly basis
for twelve (12) consecutive months. Tenants shall cooperate with the landlord/
property owner in the control, treatment, and eradication of all rodents and/or
insect infestation found, or reasonably suspected to be, in the tenant's rental
unit. A tenant's cooperation may include making any necessary preparations,
such as cleaning, vacuuming, or removing personal property for proper treatment
recommended by the licensed rodent control company. (Ord. 53-2023, 12-12-2023)
6-2-7: ABATEMENT OF PUBLIC NUISANCES:
   A.   Inspection Of Premises: Whenever complaint is made to the village
president that a public nuisance exists, or has existed, within the village, he
shall promptly notify the director of community development, or some other
village official whom the president shall designate, who shall forthwith
inspect or cause to be inspected the premises and shall make a written report
of his findings to the president. Whenever practicable, the inspecting officer
shall cause photographs to be made of the premises and shall file the same in
the office of the village clerk. (1976 Code § 12.03)
   B.   Summary Abatement:
      1.   Notice To Owner: If the inspecting officer shall determine that a
public nuisance exists on private property and that there is great and
immediate danger to the public health, safety, peace, morals or decency, the
village president may direct the chief code enforcement officer to serve a
notice on the owner, or, if the owner cannot be found, on the occupant or
person causing, permitting or maintaining such nuisance and to post a copy of
the notice on the premises. Such notice shall direct the owner, occupant or
person causing, permitting or maintaining such nuisance to abate or remove such
nuisance within twenty four (24) hours and shall state that unless such
nuisance is so abated, the village will cause the same to be abated and will
charge the cost thereof to the owner, occupant or person causing, permitting or
maintaining the same, as the case may be. (1976 Code § 12.03)
      2.   Abatement By Village: If the nuisance is not abated within the time
provided or if the owner, occupant or person causing the nuisance cannot be
found, the director of community development, or some other village official
whom the president shall designate, shall cause the abatement or removal of
such public nuisance. (1976 Code § 12.03)
   C.   Abatement By Court Action: If the inspecting officer shall determine
that a public nuisance exists on private premises but that the nature of such
nuisance is not such as to threaten great and immediate danger to the public
health, safety, peace, morals or decency, he shall file a written report of his
findings with the president, who shall cause an action to abate such nuisance
to be commenced in the name of the village. (1976 Code §
6-2-8: COST OF ABATEMENT:
In addition to any other penalty imposed by this chapter for the erection,
contrivance, creation, continuance or maintenance of a public nuisance, the
cost of abating a public nuisance by the village shall be collected as a debt
from the owner, occupant or person causing, permitting or maintaining the
nuisance, and if notice to abate the nuisance has been given to the owner, such
cost shall be assessed against the real estate as other special taxes. (1976
Code § 12.04; amd. Ord. 53-2023, 12-12-2023)
CHAPTER 3
GARBAGE AND YARD WASTE
SECTION:
6-3-1: Definitions
6-3-2: Containers Required
6-3-3: Container Specifications And Location
6-3-4: Removal Of Contents Of Containers
6-3-5: Garbage Collection Charges
6-3-6: Dumping Garbage Or Yard Waste
6-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
Terms used in this Chapter mean as follows:
GARBAGE: Discarded residential and nonresidential food and nonfood products
which excludes yard waste, more than three (3) containers of home construction
repairs or improvements, and toxic or hazardous waste.
YARD WASTE: All grass, leaves, and shrubbery trimmings that are less than
twelve inches (12") in length and less than one inch (1") in diameter. (Ord.
17-92, 5-19-1992)
6-3-2: CONTAINERS REQUIRED:
   A.   It is the duty of every owner or their agent or occupant of any house,
building, apartment in the Village where persons occupy, to provide and
maintain in good order and repair for such house, building, apartment or
structure, a container for garbage and a container for yard waste of the
material, construction and capacity prescribed and in number proportioned as
follows:
      1.   For every single-family home and townhouse, a minimum of one
container for garbage and a minimum of one separate container (or kraft-style
bag) for yard waste.
      2.   For every duplex or three (3) flat, one of each such containers for
each living quarter of such building and one container for yard waste.
      3.   All residential property larger than a three (3) flat, commercial,
office and industrial properties are required to provide a dumpster for the
pickup of garbage. The dumpster shall provide sufficient size to contain the
garbage generated by the occupant of the property.
      4.   Yard waste removal shall be the responsibility of the owner or
tenant of all residential property larger than a six (6) flat, and all
nonresidential zoned property.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit in any container for
garbage any article or thing but garbage or to deposit in any container for
yard waste any article or thing, but yard waste. (Ord. 17-92, 5-19-1992)
6-3-3: CONTAINER SPECIFICATIONS AND LOCATION:
   A.   A container for garbage shall be weather-tight and made of galvanized
metal or plastic as good with a close-fitting cover of similar material, or a
plastic bag with open end tied, with a capacity of not less than five (5) nor
more than thirty five (35) gallons. Dumpsters are also permitted where
appropriate.
   B.   Yard waste to be disposed is to be placed in a thirty five (35) gallon
paper Kraft-style bag or thirty five (35) gallon garbage containers that have
the appropriate sticker stating yard waste only. Dumpsters are also permitted
where appropriate.
   C.   Residential garbage and yard waste containers may be placed in the
parkway or in the alley right of way no earlier than twelve (12) hours prior to
the day of pickup; provided they do not obstruct or hinder the flow of traffic,
and shall be removed from the parkway or alley right of way no later than
twelve (12) hours after the day of pickup. (Ord. 17-92, 5-19-1992)
6-3-4: REMOVAL OF CONTENTS OF CONTAINERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person other than a scavenger employed or licensed
by the Village 1  or the owner, occupant, tenant or person in possession of the
premises for which containers for garbage and yard waste have been provided, to
deposit any article or thing in such containers or to remove, displace, injure,
deface, destroy, uncover or disturb such container or any portion of its
contents. (Ord. 17-92, 5-19-1992)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 3, Chapter 10 of this Code.
6-3-5: GARBAGE COLLECTION CHARGES:
   A.   Charges for residential garbage collection and yard waste collection
will be established by resolution.
   B.   Said charge shall be payable at the time of the payment or due date of
the water bill as to each piece or parcel of property involved, and shall be
made and billed on or with the water bills for each of the premises involved 1
. On parcels of property which do not receive water from the Village at the
time of the due date of water bills, separate bills shall be made for the
service charge for the collection of rubbish.
   C.   No charge shall be made in nonresidential districts where the
collection of rubbish is being made by private contract.
   D.   Each occupant, owner, tenant or agent for each nonresidential parcel of
property receiving rubbish service shall be liable therefor until such time as
the Village is notified in writing by the said occupant, owner, tenant or agent
that the collection of rubbish has been arranged for by private contract, and
in which notice shall be stated the name and address of the contractor.
   E.   Delinquent Bills: If the charge for such services is not paid within
twenty (20) days after billing date, the account will be charged a ten percent
(10%) penalty. If a partial payment is made, the penalty is also applied to the
unpaid delinquent balance. If the account remains delinquent after an
additional thirty (30) days which includes the final notice period, such
services shall be discontinued and shall not be reinstated until all unpaid
charges have been paid in full, either in U.S. currency or by a certified
negotiable instrument. (Ord. 17-92, 5-19-1992)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 8, Chapter 7 of this Code.
6-3-6: DUMPING GARBAGE OR YARD WASTE:
It is unlawful for any person to deposit, place, leave or dump any garbage or
yard waste material of any kind in or upon any street, sidewalk, alley, sewer,
parkway, park or other public or private place in the Village, other than
permitted locations. For the purpose of this Section, vehicles or parts of
vehicles not in condition for normal use shall be considered junk or garbage 1
. (Ord. 17-92, 5-19-1992)

CHAPTER 4
WEEDS; PLANTS
SECTION:
6-4-1: Definitions
6-4-2: Nuisance Greenery Declared
6-4-3: Removal; Notice Of Violation And To Remove
6-4-4: Abatement Of Nuisance Greenery By The Village
6-4-5: Lien For Removal Costs
6-4-6: Not Exclusive Remedy
6-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms shall have the meanings indicated when used in this
chapter:
REMOVAL COSTS: The total cost of the removal activity.
REMOVAL OF NUISANCE GREENERY, REMOVE, OR REMOVAL ACTIVITIES: Means or refers to
the cutting of weeds or grass, the trimming of bushes and trees, and/or the
removal of bushes, trees, and plants declared to be nuisance greenery in this
chapter. (Ord. 52-2010, 6-8-2010)
6-4-2: NUISANCE GREENERY DECLARED:
The following are hereby declared to be nuisance greenery and it shall be
unlawful to permit any such to grow or remain on property of any kind within
the village or in the manner or condition stated:
   A.   Any weeds, such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle, cocklebur or
other weeds of a like kind, found growing in any lot or tract of land in the
village, unless located on a portion thereof designated as a detention area,
wetland, or riparian area by statute or ordinance or on a duly approved and
recorded plat of subdivision.
   B.   Willows of all kinds standing in or on any public street, alley,
sidewalk, paths, or other public right of way of the village, or along the
margin thereof such that any part of them overhang such street, alley,
sidewalk, public path, or other public right of way.
   C.   The following trees or shrubs standing or located on any property such
that the fruit, berries, nuts, or seeds thereof shall fall onto any public
street, alley, sidewalk, path, or public right of way: 1) Osage orange (Maclura
pomifera), also known as horse apple, bois d'arc, or bodark; 2) mulberry
(Morus); and 3) northern catalpa (Catalpa speciosa).
   D.   Female ginkgo (Ginkgo biloba), also known as maidenhair tree.
   E.   Weeds, grass, and plants, other than trees, bushes, and horticultural
varieties of flowers and plants intended for ornamental purposes, in excess of
eight inches (8") in height, unless located in an area designated as a
detention area, wetland, or riparian area by statute or ordinance or on a duly
approved and recorded plat of subdivision.
   F.   Any flower, plant, bush, or tree, whether or not intended for
ornamental purposes, that overhangs or protrudes into the space within eight
feet (8') of the surface of any public sidewalk, path, or pedestrian right of
way or within fifteen feet (15') of the surface of any public street, road,
alley, or other vehicular right of way, unless located in an area designated as
a detention area, wetland, or riparian area by statute or ordinance or on a
duly approved and recorded plat of subdivision. (Ord. 52-2010, 6-8-2010)
6-4-3: REMOVAL; NOTICE OF VIOLATION AND TO REMOVE:
It shall be the duty of the chief code enforcement officer, or his or her
designee, to serve or cause to be served upon the owner, tenant, occupant, or
person in charge of any premises on which nuisance greenery as set forth in
section
6-4-2 of this chapter is permitted to grow in violation of this chapter a
notice of violation and order to remove such nuisance greenery. Service of the
notice of violation and order to remove may be by personal service, posting of
copy thereof on the premises, or by certified U.S. mail, return receipt
requested. Such nuisance greenery shall be removed within seven (7) calendar
days after service of the notice of violation and order to remove. The notice
of violation and order to remove shall state the date by which the nuisance
greenery shall be removed. (Ord. 52-2010, 6-8-2010)
6-4-4: ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE GREENERY BY THE VILLAGE:
If the owner, tenant, agent or person in charge of the premises fails to remove
the nuisance greenery within the time stated in the notice of violation and
order to remove, the village, through its own person or through its authorized
agent or contractor, may abate the nuisance greenery by entering upon the
premises, and, if necessary, remove the nuisance greenery at the expense of the
owner, tenant, or occupant of, and/or other person responsible for such
premises. Express authority to enter upon said premises and remove the nuisance
greenery as provided in this section is hereby conferred upon the village. The
village shall submit a statement to the owner, tenant, occupant, or person in
charge of the premises or his or her agent for the removal cost incurred by the
village for the removal activity. (Ord. 52-2010, 6-8-2010)
6-4-5: LIEN FOR REMOVAL COSTS:
The village, and/or its authorized agent or contractor, shall have a lien upon
the premises for the removal cost as provided for in section 11-20-15 of the
Illinois municipal code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-15, which
section is incorporated herein by reference as if fully set out, and, if the
total removal cost shall not be paid within thirty (30) days of submission of
the statement therefor to the owner, tenant, agent or person in charge of the
premises, the village, and/or its authorized agent or contractor, may enforce
such lien as provided in said section of the Illinois municipal code. (Ord. 52-
2010, 6-8-2010)
6-4-6: NOT EXCLUSIVE REMEDY:
The provisions of this chapter shall not be the exclusive remedy of the
village, and/or its authorized agent or contractor, in regard to the removal of
nuisance greenery and the liening of the premises for the removal cost
therefor, but shall be in addition to the remedy provided in section 11-20-7(d)
of the Illinois municipal code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-7, for
abandoned residential properties, and other remedies that may be conferred by
statute or law. (Ord. 52-2010, 6-8-2010)
CHAPTER 5
DUTCH ELM DISEASE 1
(Rep. by Ord. 32-2019, 5-28-2019)

CHAPTER 6
POLLUTION CONTROL
SECTION:
6-6-1: Title
6-6-2: Definitions
6-6-3: Adoption Of State Regulations
6-6-4: Administration And Enforcement
6-6-5: Appeals
6-6-6: Potential Air Polluting Equipment
6-6-7: Air Pollution Emission Standards
6-6-8: Sulfur Dioxide Limitation
6-6-9: Toxics
6-6-10: Tests
6-6-11: Fees
6-6-12: Persons Liable
6-6-13: Penalties
6-6-14: New Regional Pollution Control Facility Site Approval Requests
6-6-1: TITLE:
This Chapter shall be known, cited and referred to as the VILLAGE OF
BENSENVILLE POLLUTION CONTROL ORDINANCE. (1976 Code § 15.01)
6-6-2: DEFINITIONS:
Terms used in this Chapter mean as follows:
AIR CONTAMINANT: Particulate matter, dust, fumes, gas, mist, smoke or vapor, or
any condition thereof.
AIR CONTAMINANT SOURCE: Any and all sources of emission of air contaminants,
whether privately or publicly owned or operated. Without limiting the
generality of the foregoing, this term includes all types of business,
commercial and industrial plants and stations, buildings and other structures
of all types, including single and multiple-family residences, apartments,
houses, office buildings, hotels, restaurants, schools, hospitals, churches and
other institutional buildings, automobiles, trucks, tractors, buses and other
motor vehicles, garages and vending and service locations and stations,
railroad locomotives, ships, boats and other waterborne craft, portable fuel
burning equipment, incinerators of all types, indoor and outdoor, refuse dumps
and piles, and all stack and other chimney outlets from any of the foregoing.
AIR POLLUTION: Presence in the outdoor atmosphere of one or more air
contaminants in sufficient quantities and of such characteristics and duration
as to be injurious to human, plant or animal life or to property, or which
unreasonably interfere with the enjoyment of life and property.
AIR QUALITY STANDARD: Ambient air quality goal established for the purpose of
protecting public health and welfare.
COMBUSTIBLE REFUSE: Any solid or liquid combustible waste material containing
carbon in a free or combined state.
EMISSION STANDARD: That level of air contaminant emitted from an air
contaminant source which is established by authority.
ENVIRONMENTAL POLLUTION: All forms of contaminants, including but not limited
to water, air and noise pollution and solid wastes.
EQUIPMENT: Any fuel burning, refuse burning or combustion process devices or
apparatus used for the burning of fuel or combustible material from which the
products of combustion are emitted. Also this shall include apparatus which
generates heat and may emit products of combustion; and manufacturing,
chemical, metallurgical or mechanical processes which may emit air
contaminants.
ORGANIC MATERIALS: Chemical compounds of carbon, excluding carbon monoxide,
carbon dioxide, carbonic acid, metallic carbides, metallic carbonates and
ammonium carbonate.
ORGANIC SOLVENT: Organic material which is liquid at standard atmospheric
conditions and which is used as dissolvers, viscosity reducers, cleaning
agents, diluents or thinners.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation,
association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision, State
agency, or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or
assigns.
PHOTOCHEMICALLY REACTIVE SOLVENT: Any solvent with an aggregate of more than
twenty percent (20%) of its total volume composed of chemical compounds
classified below or which exceeds any of the following individual percentage
composition limitations, referred to the total volume of solvent:
   A.   A combination of hydrocarbons, alcohols, aldehydes, esters, ethers or
ketones having an olefinic or cyclo-olefinic type of unsaturation: five percent
(5%);
   B.   A combination of aromatic compounds with eight (8) or more carbon atoms
to the molecule, except ethylbenzene: eight percent (8%);
   C.   A combination of ethylbenzene, ketones having branched hydrocarbon
structures, trichloroethylene or toluene: twenty percent (20%).
RINGELMANN CHART: The chart which is described in the U.S. Bureau of Mines
Information Circular 7718, and on which are illustrated graduated shades of
gray to black for use in estimating the light obscuring power of smoke. (1976
Code § 15.02)
6-6-3: ADOPTION OF STATE REGULATIONS:
   A.   The following rules and regulations of the Illinois Pollution Control
Board are hereby adopted and incorporated by reference into the provisions of
this Chapter, copies of which are available at the office of the Village Clerk:
      1.   State of Illinois, Pollution Control Board, Air Pollution Rules and
Regulations;
      2.   State of Illinois, Pollution Control Board, Water Pollution Rules
and Regulations;
      3.   State of Illinois, Pollution Control Board, Solid Waste Rules and
Regulations; and
      4.   State of Illinois, Pollution Control Board, Noise Rules and
Regulations. (1976 Code § 15.041)
Said Noise Rules and Regulations are hereby amended by deleting the exception
application of Rules 202 through 207 of said Noise Regulations as applies to
sound emitted from equipment being used for construction and by further
modifying said rules to provide that Rules 202 through 207 shall apply to sound
emitted from equipment being used for construction from the hours of seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M. to seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. (Ord. 77-77, 8-11-1977)
   B.   The pollution control officer or his designated deputy shall administer
the provisions of the above-stated rules and regulations throughout the
Village.
   C.   If any provisions of the above-stated rules and regulations are in
conflict with any ordinance of the Village, the more restrictive provision
shall govern. (1976 Code § 15.041)
6-6-4: ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Pollution Control Officer: The Village President and Board of Trustees
are hereby authorized to designate the pollution control officer and enforcing
officers, who shall exercise the duties set forth in this Chapter.
   B.   Duties Of Pollution Control Officer: It shall be the duty of the
pollution control officer:
      1.   To supervise the execution of all laws, ordinances, rules and
regulations pertaining to environmental pollution.
      2.   To institute necessary proceedings to prosecute violations of all
ordinances pertaining to environmental pollution and compel the prevention and
abatement of environmental contaminants, and nuisances arising therefrom.
      3.   To examine and approve the plans of pollution control devices
proposed, installed, constructed, reconstructed, repaired or added to, in any
building, location or on any premises within the boundaries of the Village.
      4.   To cause inspections to be made of pollution control devices.
      5.   To investigate complaints, make observations of contaminant
conditions and take the necessary and proper action to abate nuisances
therefrom.
      6.   To advise, consult and cooperate with other governmental agencies in
the furtherance of the purpose of this Chapter.
      7.   To collect, publish and disseminate appropriate educational
literature and other information to the public for the purpose of advising of
the necessity, purpose and methods of pollution prevention.
      8.   To issue all permits, certificates, notices or other matters
required under the provisions of this Chapter; and to notify all persons
concerned of any decision he may render and to provide such persons with an
opportunity to be heard.
      9.   To enlist the cooperation of civic, technical scientific and
educational groups, societies and organizations in respect to the reduction and
abatement of environmental contaminants.
      10.   To cause to be instituted in the court legal proceedings by the
Village Attorney to compel compliance with any order or determination entered
on recommendation of the pollution control officer and pollution committee.
      11.   To appoint deputy pollution control officers to perform such duties
and exercise such powers as are delegated by the pollution control officer.
      12.   To summarily abate all pollution done in violation of any Village
ordinance pertaining to environmental pollution. The pollution control officer
shall serve notice on the owner whose property is the source of such pollution
at least twenty four (24) hours prior to such summary abatement. If the owner
cannot be found, said notice shall be served on the occupant or person causing,
permitting or maintaining such pollution and a copy of said notice shall be
posted on the premises. Such notice shall direct such owner, occupant or
person, as the case may be, to abate or remove such pollution within twenty
four (24) hours and shall state that unless such pollution is so abated, the
Village will cause the same to be abated and will charge the cost thereof to
said owner, occupant or person, as the case may be. If the pollution is not
abated within the time provided or if the owner, occupant or person cannot be
found, the pollution control officer shall cause the abatement or removal of
such nuisance and charge the cost thereof to the owner, occupant or person, as
the case may be. (1976 Code § 15.03)
   C.   Right Of Entry: In the discharge of his duties, the pollution control
officer or his authorized inspectors shall have the authority to enter, at any
reasonable hour, any building, structure or premises within the incorporated
area of the Village to enforce the provisions of this Chapter; provided,
however, no entry shall be made without the owner's consent, unless made in the
manner provided by law. (1976 Code § 15.03; amd. 1981 Code)
The Village Board of Trustees shall authorize the pollution control officer a
badge of office for himself and his representatives which shall be displayed
for the purpose of identification; also an identification card as is
customarily issued by the Village.
The assistance and cooperation of health, police, legal and other officers
shall be available to the pollution control officer as required in the
performance of his duties. (1976 Code § 15.03)
6-6-5: APPEALS:
   A.   The Village Board of Trustees shall have the duty and power to hear and
determine appeals for decisions and orders of the pollution control officer and
to confirm, vary or reverse any such decision or order.
   B.   Any person aggrieved and complaining of an order or decision of the
pollution control officer may take an appeal to the Board of Trustees within
twenty (20) days of the order, decision or ruling complained of, by filing with
the pollution control officer and the Village Clerk written notice that he
intends to appeal such order, decision or ruling, and in said notice shall give
a name and address where notices can be served upon him.
   C.   The pollution control officer, upon receipt of the notice of appeal,
shall forthwith transmit to the Board of Trustees all papers and documents
constituting the record upon which his decision, order or ruling was based. The
Board of Trustee shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal and
give due notice thereof by mail to the parties in interest and decide said
appeal within a reasonable time. The notice of appeal shall act as a stay of
any decision, ruling or order until either approved, modified or set aside by
the Board of Trustees. A fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be paid to the
Village Treasurer at the time the notice of appeal is filed with the Village
Clerk.
   D.   The Board of Trustees shall forthwith, by certified mail, notify all
parties of its decision, as well as all members of the pollution committee.
(1976 Code § 15.04)
6-6-6: POTENTIAL AIR POLLUTING EQUIPMENT:
   A.   Installation Permit: No person shall construct, install or alter any
fuel burning, combustion, or process equipment or any equipment pertaining
thereto for use within the incorporated areas of the Village until an
application, including suitable plans and specifications of the equipment and
structures or buildings used in connection therewith has been filed in
duplicate by the person or his agent in the office of, and has been approved
by, the pollution control officer and an installation permit has been issued by
the building inspector for such construction, installation or alteration.
   B.   Plans And Specifications: The abovementioned plans and specifications
shall show the form and dimension of the fuel burning, combustion or process
equipment, more particularly the proposed boiler, furnace, fuel burner, stack,
ducts, drains and sewer connections, together with the description and
dimensions of the building or part thereof in which such equipment is to be
located. The character of the fuel to be used, the maximum quantity of such
fuel to be burned per hour, the character and concentration of liquid wastes,
the operating requirements, and the use to be made of the equipment shall be
stated.
   C.   Examination Of Application For Permit: Whenever an application is filed
with the pollution control officer, he shall thereupon examine and either
approve or reject same; and in the event of approval, he shall notify the
building inspector to issue the permit.
   D.   Exceptions: An installation permit is not required:
      1.   In the case of routine maintenance work or minor alterations or
repairs which do not adversely affect the production, emission or discharge of
smoke, dust, fly-ash, soot, fumes, solid or gaseous products of combustion,
solid or liquid waste products; or
      2.   In the case of an emergency repair where serious consequences would
otherwise result, provided that application for the necessary installation
permit is filed otherwise in accordance with this Section on the first business
day following commencement of the repair work.
   E.   Proof Of Responsibility; Bond: If the proposed plans and specifications
submitted pursuant to this Section are not sufficiently complete, in the
judgment of the pollution control officer, to show that the equipment or device
for which such plans and specifications were submitted can consistently comply
with and can be operated within the provisions of this Chapter, either because
the design or process is unconventional or untried, or because the person has
elected to omit confidential details, or because there is insufficient data on
which to estimate the air pollution potential, the pollution control officer is
authorized to require as a condition precedent to the issuance of an
installation permit or certificate of operation, proof of financial
responsibility and of ability to make any changes that may be required after
construction to insure compliance with the provisions of this Chapter. Such
proof, in the discretion of the pollution control officer, may be a written
statement to such effect, signed by the owner or a responsible officer of a
financially sound organization, or a written guarantee of performance signed by
a responsible supplier or contractor or other responsible person. The
responsibility of any such person or soundness of any such organization shall
be a matter within the judgment of the pollution control officer, subject to
the right of appeal.
In the event that he is not given adequate proof of financial responsibility
and of ability to make any changes that may be required, the pollution control
officer may require any such person, as owner, lessee, operator, supplier,
contractor, vendor or other person, to file with the pollution control officer
a surety bond running to the Village in the sum of not to exceed fifty thousand
dollars ($50,000.00), executed by such person, as principal, and two (2) or
more sureties, or a surety company authorized to do business in this State.
   F.   Commencement Of Work: If construction, installation or alteration is
not started within one year of the date of the installation permit, the permit
shall become void and all fees shall be forfeited. An extension not to exceed
six (6) months may be granted by the Board of Trustees through appeal
procedures upon proper application.
   G.   Operating Permit: After any work of erecting, constructing,
reconstructing, installing, altering or repairing any fuel burning equipment is
completed, the pollution control officer shall inspect the same, and, if such
work conforms to the application, plans and specifications filed in respect
thereof and to the provisions of this Chapter, he shall authorize the issuance
of a permit known as an operating permit, to the person to whom the necessary
installation permit was issued, upon payment of the prescribed fee. The
operating permit shall be posted in a conspicuous position adjacent to the
equipment.
   H.   Subsequent Violation: The authorization of the issuance by the
pollution control officer of any installation permit or operating permit shall
not be held to exempt the person to whom the permit has been issued or who is
in possession of the same, from prosecution for violation of this Chapter.
   I.   Annual Inspections; Notice To Correct Defects: Equipment installed
under this Section shall be inspected annually by the pollution control
officer. If, at the time of the annual inspection, it is found that the
equipment is in such condition that it cannot be operated within the provisions
of this Chapter, the pollution control officer is authorized to give notice in
writing to the person owning, operating or in charge of such equipment of the
defects found and an order to correct, repair or replace the defective
equipment. Failure to comply with this order within thirty (30) days from its
date shall be a violation of this Section and the pollution control officer is
hereby authorized to seal the equipment. No person shall violate the seal on
any equipment that has been sealed at the direction of the pollution control
officer unless authorized by him in writing to do so.
   J.   Variances: The Village Board of Trustees is hereby given authority for
the granting of individual variances for any fuel burning, combustion or
process equipment or device, beyond the limitations prescribed in this Chapter
whenever it is found, upon the presentation of adequate proof, that compliance
with any provision of this Chapter, or any rule, regulation, requirement or
order of the pollution control officer will result in an arbitrary and
unreasonable taking of property or in the practical closing and elimination of
any lawful business, occupation or activity, in either case without a
sufficient corresponding benefit or advantage to the people in the reduction of
pollution; in such case, there shall be prescribed other and different
requirements, not more onerous, applicable to plants or equipment involved.
   K.   Period Of Grace: In the event any person is compelled to, or deems it
advisable to, install any new equipment, processes or devices, appliances,
means or methods, including needed pollution control equipment, in order to
comply with any provisions of this Chapter, such person may obtain a period of
grace in order to effect such compliance in accordance with the following
procedure. To obtain such period of grace, a written request shall be filed
with the pollution control officer by any such person, and shall set forth
that, following normal good operating procedures, it is impossible in the
operation of any plant, fuel burning, combustion or process equipment or
devices, or apparatus, to operate the same in compliance with the requirements
of this Chapter. The request shall also state evidence satisfactory to the
pollution control officer that such person has taken, or will take, all steps
necessary to provide for future compliance with the provisions of this Chapter.
The pollution control officer shall be assured that the acquisition and
installation of the proper equipment, processes, devices or appliances or
control equipment will be effected within the period of time specified. (1976
Code § 15.05)
6-6-7: AIR POLLUTION EMISSION STANDARDS:
   A.   Established: Air quality standards are ambient air quality goals
established for the purpose of protecting public health and welfare. The levels
of air quality designated by the standards are designed to protect against
injury to human, plant or animal life; they are further intended to allow
maximum enjoyment of property consistent with the intent of this Chapter.
      The first use of air resources is to sustain life. Air entering the
respiratory tract must not menace health. Therefore, the air quality standards
set must, as a minimum, provide air which will not adversely affect, through
acute or chronic symptoms, the health of the community.
      The air quality standards set here will provide a basis for planning to
achieve cleaner air. Even though in certain areas of the Village the quality of
the air may be lower than the standards, they are not a license allowing
unnecessary degradation of the air, going against the intent of the act which
requires a maintenance of the purity of the air resources of the State.
      The standards have also been designed for use as a basis for the
development of implementation plans for the abatement and control of pollutants
emissions from existing sources including development of air contaminant
emission limitations and the setting of long- and short-range objectives for
reduction of total emission of air contaminants as determined by emission
inventories. And they will be used in the determination of air pollution
control emission limitations for future installations to insure that urban and
economic growth trends do not add to community air pollution problems.
   B.   Burning Restrictions:
      1.   Open Burning: No person shall cause, suffer, allow or permit open
burning of refuse or other matter. (1976 Code § 15.06)
      2.   Bonfires: No person shall kindle or maintain any bonfire or
authorize any such fire to be kindled on any private land unless a permit is
issued by the pollution control officer or by the fire inspector of the
Village. Exempt from the provisions of this subsection are fires used in the
preparation of foods. (Ord. 25-91, 9-17-1991)
   C.   Air Contaminants Prohibited; Ringelmann Test: A person shall not
discharge into the atmosphere from any single source of emission any air
contaminants for a period or periods aggregating more than three (3) minutes in
any one hour which is:
      1.   As dark or darker in shade as that designated as No. 1 on the
Ringelmann Chart; or
      2.   Of such opacity as to obscure an observer's view to a degree equal
to or greater than does smoke described in subsection C1 of this Section.
   D.   Nuisance, Air Contaminants: A person shall not discharge from any
source such quantities of air contaminants or other material which cause
injury, detriment, nuisance or annoyance to any other person or to the public
or which endanger the comfort, repose, health or safety of any such persons or
the public or which cause or have a natural tendency to cause injury or damage
to business or property. (1976 Code § 15.06)
6-6-8: SULFUR DIOXIDE LIMITATION:
   A.   No person shall cause or permit the use of, or if intended for use in
the Village, the purchase, sale, offer for sale, storage or transportation of
fuel which, as determined by the methods of the American Society for Testing
and Materials, contains more than the following percentages of sulfur by
weight:
      For a period of two (2) years, beginning April 5, 1971: fuel 2.5%.
      For a period of eighteen (18) months, beginning April 5, 1973: fuel 2.0%.
      After October 5, 1974: fuel 1.5%.
   B.   Upon the application of any person engaged in the operation of fuel
burning equipment, the pollution control officer, with the approval of the
Board of Trustees, may issue a certificate of operation in those cases wherein
the applicant shall establish that the fuel burning equipment is operated in
such a manner or is equipped with such control apparatus, as to continually
prevent the emission of any sulfur compound or compounds in amounts greater
than those that would be emitted from the burning (in the same fuel burning
equipment without such control apparatus) of fuel containing any amount of
sulfur by weight not in excess of the maximum amount permitted at the
applicable time by this Section. (1976 Code § 15.07)
6-6-9: TOXICS:
No activity or operation shall cause, at any time, the discharge of toxic
matter into the atmosphere in such concentrations as to be detrimental to or
endanger the public health, safety or welfare, or cause injury or damage to
property or business or be needlessly destructive of any insect, plant or
animal life which contributes to the general welfare. (1976 Code § 15.11)
6-6-10: TESTS:
   A.   If the pollution control officer has reasonable cause to believe that
any equipment or fuel is in violation of this Chapter, the pollution control
officer may order the owner or lessee of the equipment or fuel, or his agent to
conduct and pay for such tests as are necessary in the opinion of the pollution
control officer to determine whether the equipment or fuel is in violation of
this Chapter and to submit the test results to the pollution control officer
within ten (10) days after the tests are completed.
   B.   Such tests shall be conducted in a manner approved by the pollution
control officer. If any part of the test is conducted at a place other than the
site where the equipment or fuel is located, that part of the test shall be
certified by a responsible laboratory.
   C.   The owner or lessee, or his agent, shall notify the pollution control
officer of the time and place of a test at least seven (7) days before the
commencement of a test. Reasonable facilities shall be made available for the
pollution control officer to witness the test. (1976 Code § 15.12)
6-6-11: FEES:
Fees required for permits, certificates and inspection of equipment and other
sources of emission shall be established by resolution of the Village President
and Board of Trustees. All fees shall be collected by the Village Clerk for
deposit with the Village Treasurer. (1976 Code § 15.13)
6-6-12: PERSONS LIABLE:
All persons owning, operating or in charge or control of any equipment who
violate or cause, suffer or allow any violation of this Chapter, either as
owners, occupants, managers or agents, shall be jointly and severally liable to
the penalties imposed by this Chapter. (1976 Code § 15.14)
6-6-13: PENALTIES:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of or who fails to perform any
duty imposed by this Chapter, or who violates any terms or orders of the
pollution control officer promulgated pursuant to this Chapter, shall be liable
to a penalty of not to exceed the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for
each violation, and an additional penalty of not to exceed five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each day during which the violation continues, or by imprisonment
in the County jail for a period not to exceed six (6) months, or by both such
fine and imprisonment, and in addition thereto, such person may be enjoined
from continuing such violation as hereinafter provided.
After one conviction for any violation of the terms and provisions of this
Chapter, the Board of Trustees may suspend, for a period not to exceed thirty
(30) days, the license of any Village licensed business so convicted. After two
(2) convictions for violation of the terms and provisions of this Chapter, the
Board of Trustees may revoke the license of any Village licensed business so
convicted. Such suspension or revocation may be in addition to any other
penalty which is provided herein. (1976 Code § 15.15)
6-6-14: NEW REGIONAL POLLUTION CONTROL FACILITY SITE APPROVAL REQUESTS:
Village Ordinance 10-93 establishing a procedure for New Regional Pollution
Control Facility Site Approval Requests in the Village is hereby adopted and
made a part hereof by reference. Three (3) copies of said Ordinance shall be
and remain on file in the office of the Village Clerk. (Ord. 10-93, 3-16-1993)
TITLE 7
RESERVED
(Ord. 40-2015, 10-27-2015)
TITLE 8
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS AND SIDEWALKS
SECTION:
8-1-1: Grades, Village Datum
8-1-2: Sidewalks
8-1-3: Snow Removal
8-1-4: Obstructing Streets
8-1-5: Buildings Encroaching On Street
8-1-6: Lights On Obstructions
8-1-7: Deposits On Or Near Streets
8-1-8: Barbed Wire Fences
8-1-9: Obstructing Sewer Or Culvert
8-1-10: Open Gateways
8-1-11: Tree Line Along Streets
8-1-1: GRADES, VILLAGE DATUM:
   A.   Village Datum: The base or datum for the Village levels is hereby
established and located at the horizontal plane of 667.28 feet (USGS) above sea
level, at the chiseled square on the northeast corner of the concrete base of
the first light standard west of Church Road in the Village Hall parking lot.
   B.   Reference For All Grades: All grades hereafter fixed or established
shall have reference to the base or datum plane herein and hereby established.
   C.   Permission Required, Change Grade: The establishment of any grade shall
not be construed to confer any power on any person to fill, raise or lower any
street or sidewalk without having first obtained permission so to do from the
Board of Trustees. (1976 Code § 6.01)
8-1-2: SIDEWALKS:
   A.   Permit To Construct: No person shall construct any concrete sidewalk
within the Village without first obtaining a permit from the Village President
and Board of Trustees.
   B.   Width Of Walks: All sidewalks which may hereafter be constructed within
the Village shall be constructed under the supervision of the building
inspector, and unless otherwise ordered by the President and Board of Trustees,
shall be of uniform width of five feet (5').
   C.   Established Lines: No sidewalk shall be constructed or laid except upon
the lines and grades established or given by the Village.
   D.   Construction Of Concrete Sidewalks: All sidewalks that may hereafter be
constructed in the Village shall be constructed of concrete under the
supervision of the building inspector in accordance with the specifications
prescribed by the Village.
   E.   Breaking Walks: Any person who shall break or otherwise injure any
sidewalk shall, within a reasonable time thereafter, cause the same to be well
repaired. (1976 Code § 6.16)
8-1-3: SNOW REMOVAL:
No owner of any property situated in any zoning district shall place, deposit
or dump snow removed from the sidewalks and driveways on said property onto the
public streets or public alleyways. (Ord. 26-89, 5-16-1989)
8-1-4: OBSTRUCTING STREETS:
   A.   Street Obstructions: The streets, sidewalks and alleys of the Village
shall be kept free and clear of all obstructions, encumbrances and
encroachments for the use of the public, and shall not be used or occupied in
any other way than is provided in this Code. (1976 Code § 6.05)
   B.   Building Materials Or Other Objects:
      1.   No person shall encumber or obstruct any street, sidewalk or alley
in the Village by placing thereon any building materials or any article or
thing without having first obtained written permission from the Director of
Public Works. (Ord. 36-78, 11-16-1978)
      2.   No person shall place any object, except mailboxes and requisite
posts, in a public parkway unless it will break away in a controlled manner
during an impact with a motor vehicle which has left the roadway.
Any rock, boulder or other decorative object installed on any portion of the
public parkway in violation of this Section shall be relocated or removed
within thirty (30) days after written notice from the Department of Community
Development. (Ord. 46-94, 10-4-1994)
   C.   Contractors In Streets: All persons who do work in any sidewalk, street
or other thoroughfare in the Village shall have all sand, dirt and rubbish
cleared off the sidewalk, street or thoroughfare after the work is completed.
(1976 Code § 6.07)
   D.   Contractors Obstructing Streets: It shall be lawful for persons
employed to repair or pave any street in the Village to place an obstruction
across such street or roadway for the purpose of preserving the part so
repaired or made until the same shall be fit for use, leaving at all times a
sufficient passage for pedestrians. No person shall, without the consent of the
Director of Public Works or the person superintending such paving, remove any
such obstruction. No person repairing or paving a street shall obstruct more
than the space of one block and one intersection at the same time in any
street, or keep the same blocked for more than two (2) days after the roadway
is finished. (1976 Code § 6.08)
   E.   Fencing And Lights: It shall be the duty of every person doing work in
any street, alley or sidewalk or depositing materials thereon, where such work
is left exposed and would be dangerous to the public, to erect a fence or
railing at such excavations or work in such a manner as to prevent danger to
persons who may be traveling on such streets. It shall be the duty of such
person to place upon such railing or fence suitable sufficient lights through
the night during the performance of said work. (1976 Code § 6.09)
   F.   Removal Of Obstructions: The Director of Public Works or any police
officer may order any article or thing which may encumber or encroach upon or
obstruct any street, alley or sidewalk to be removed. If such article or thing
shall not be removed within the time specified in the notice to the owner or
person in charge thereof to remove the same, or if the owner cannot be readily
found for the purpose of such notice, the Director of Public Works or police
officer shall cause the same to be removed to some suitable place to be
designated by the Director of Public Works. The expense of such removal may be
recovered from the person causing such obstruction. (1976 Code § 6.10)
8-1-5: BUILDINGS ENCROACHING ON STREET:
No person shall erect or place any building, in whole or in part, upon or
projecting over any street, alley, sidewalk or other public ground. No building
shall be less than three feet (3') from the lot lines. (1976 Code § 6.11)
8-1-6: LIGHTS ON OBSTRUCTIONS:
Any person having the use of any portion of the street or sidewalk for the
purpose of erecting or repairing any building, or for any other purpose, shall
cause red lights to be placed in a conspicuous place on such obstruction each
night during the time such obstruction remains. (1976 Code § 6.12)
8-1-7: DEPOSITS ON OR NEAR STREETS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit in any manner in or upon
any street, sidewalk, alley, park or public place in the Village, or in any
drain, sewer or receiving basin within the jurisdiction of the Village, any
material refuse or foreign matter or substance of any kind. This subsection
shall not apply to the deposit of material under a permit authorized by the
Village, nor to goods, wares and merchandise deposited upon any sidewalk, alley
or other public place temporarily in the necessary course of trade, and removed
therefrom within two (2) hours after being so deposited, nor to things or
articles deposited in or conducted into the Village sewerage system through
drains in accordance with the ordinances of the Village relating thereto. (1976
Code § 6.13)
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit anywhere within the
jurisdiction of the Village any material, refuse, substance or foreign matter
of any kind in such a manner that such material may be carried and deposited by
the action of the elements into or upon any street, sidewalk, alley, park or
other public place, or into any drain, sewer or receiving basin within the
jurisdiction of the Village. This shall not apply to the deposit of material
under a permit authorized by the Village. This subsection shall not apply to
the proper use of manure or fertilizer upon any lawn or garden. (1976 Code §
6.14)
8-1-8: BARBED WIRE FENCES:
No person shall maintain any barbed wire along any sidewalk within the Village.
Wherever there exists such a barbed wire fence, the owner or person maintaining
the wire shall be notified by the Director of Public Works to remove the same
within five (5) days from the date of such notice. (1976 Code § 6.15)
8-1-9: OBSTRUCTING SEWER OR CULVERT:
No person shall stop or obstruct the passage of the water of any street or
public sewer, culvert, water pipe or hydrant laid or placed by the Village.
(1976 Code § 42.15)
8-1-10: OPEN GATEWAYS:
No person shall keep or leave open any cellar door, or grating of any vault, on
any street or sidewalk, or permit the same to be left open. (1976 Code § 42.16)
8-1-11: TREE LINE ALONG STREETS:
The tree line on streets is hereby fixed at nine feet (9') from the property
line. The tree line inside the property is hereby fixed at not less than two
feet (2') from the property line. (Ord. 104, 3-7-1905)
CHAPTER 2
EXCAVATIONS; SIDEWALK AND PARKWAY USE
SECTION:
8-2-1: Permit Required
8-2-2: Deposit Required, Use Of
8-2-3: Requirements
8-2-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person shall excavate in or tunnel under any street, alley or sidewalk, or
operate vehicles over any parkway or sidewalk without a permit therefor. (1976
Code § 6.04)
8-2-2: DEPOSIT REQUIRED, USE OF:
   A.   Requirement: No permit shall be issued for the construction of any
building or structure, or for any other work in the Village, which will
necessitate or entail the driving of vehicles or equipment over any parkway or
sidewalk within the Village, or which will necessitate or entail any excavation
in or tunneling or boring in or under any street, sidewalk, alley or public way
in the Village unless there is first deposited with the Village the sum of five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for any work under parkway, including the sidewalk,
and one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for any work in or under a street, alley
or public way, in cash or certified check payable to the Village, which deposit
shall be retained by the Village to insure that any damage to Village property
in connection with the work will be properly corrected.
   B.   Return Of Deposit: Upon the completion of all such work and
restoration, the Director of Public Works shall make a final inspection of the
completed work. The Village shall retain two hundred dollars ($200.00) of the
original deposit for a period of thirty (30) days following the completion of
such work to insure the quality of the work done.
If, after the expiration of the thirty (30) days, the Director of Public Works
shall find that the work has been completed in a satisfactory manner and all
restoration has been completed, the Village shall return to the depositor the
balance of the deposit after first deducting the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) to
cover inspections required hereunder, and any part of such deposit which was
used to defray the cost of the work done by the Village in accordance with the
terms thereof. (1981 Code)
   C.   Use Of Deposit: Each deposit as herein required shall be accompanied by
an agreement by the depositor that such deposit may be used in accordance with
the provisions of this Chapter. (1976 Code § 6.04)
8-2-3: REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Restoring Surface: Any such excavation, tunneling or boring shall be
filled and repaired, and the street, sidewalk, alley or public way shall be
returned to its previous condition as quickly as is practicable promptly after
the work has been completed and proper inspections, if any, have been made.
   B.   Backfill: The backfill of any such excavation, tunneling or boring
shall be conducted in accordance with the Standard Specifications for Road and
Bridge Construction as outlined under section 31, Porous Granular Backfill,
adopted by the State of Illinois, Department of Highways, January 2, 1958. If
the excavation, tunneling or boring is not properly backfilled within five (5)
days after the completion of the work to be done, the Village shall backfill
such excavation, tunneling or boring or have the same backfilled, paying the
cost thereof from such deposit.
   C.   Resurfacing: Resurfacing shall be done in such a manner as to be equal
to the existing surface prior to the commencement of work. Such resurfacing
shall be done not earlier than twenty one (21) days after the backfilling nor
later than thirty (30) days after such backfilling, and if such resurfacing is
not done within the time specified, the Village shall do such resurfacing or
have such resurfacing done, paying the cost thereof from such deposit. No
resurfacing shall be done without at least twenty four (24) hours' advance
notice to the Director of Public Works, who shall either in person or by his
inspectors be present at the time such work is done. (1976 Code § 6.04)
CHAPTER 3
PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
8-3-1: Permit Required
8-3-2: Bond Required
8-3-3: Plans And Specifications
8-3-4: Bidding On Public Works Or Other Public Improvements
8-3-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No street, sidewalk, water main, sewer, lighting system or any other public
improvement on public property or on property intended to be dedicated for
public use shall hereafter be constructed in the Village by private contract
until a permit or approval therefor shall have been obtained. (Ord. 9-99, 2-3-
1999)
8-3-2: BOND REQUIRED:
Any person obtaining a permit shall give bond conditioned that he will suitably
guard and protect any excavation or obstruction and defend, save, keep harmless
and indemnify the Village of and from any and all actions, suits, costs,
damages and expenses, including attorney fees, which shall or may at any time
happen to come to it for or on account of any injuries or damages received or
sustained by any party or parties by or from acts or omissions of the applicant
or his services in doing such work; and that he will restore such street,
sidewalk or public property to its former condition and complete such quality
work as quickly as possible and when completed notify the Village Engineer of
such fact; and guaranteeing that such work so made in the public streets,
sidewalks and public properties and in properties to be dedicated for such
public use, is made and constructed in a good and workmanlike manner and of
good and proper material and that the same shall not deteriorate, cave in or
require repair or reconstruction for a period of at least two (2) years from
the time of the approval of such work as herein mentioned. The bond shall be in
the form of an irrevocable and unconditional letter of credit, approved as to
form by the Village Attorney and in an amount equal to one hundred ten percent
(110%) of the estimated cost of the work to be performed. (Ord. 9-99, 2-23-
1999)
8-3-3: PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
No improvements shall be constructed which do not conform with the requirements
set forth in this Code and all such plans and specifications shall be prepared
by or under the direction of the Village Engineer and all such work shall be
done under the supervision of the Village Engineer. In any case where plans and
specifications shall be prepared by an engineer other than the Village
Engineer, such plans and specifications shall be reviewed by the Village
Engineer, and the person submitting said plans shall pay to the Village, in
addition to the permit fee, a sum equal to one and one-half percent (1.5%) of
the estimated cost of such improvements as costs for reviewing said plans and
specifications. (1976 Code § 6.03)
8-3-4: BIDDING ON PUBLIC WORKS OR OTHER PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS:
   A.   For any public work or other public improvement to be undertaken by the
Village, which is not to be paid for in whole or in part by special assessment
or special taxation, when the expense thereof will exceed ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) (or such other minimum amount which may from time to time be
provided by the Illinois Municipal Code), the public work or public improvement
shall be constructed in the following manner:
      1.   By contract let to the lowest responsible bidder after advertising
for bids; or
      2.   By a contract let without advertising for bids if previously
authorized by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of all of the Trustees then holding
office; or
      3.   If previously authorized by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of all of the
Trustees then holding office, the Village Director of Public Works or such
other proper officer designated by ordinance, shall superintend and cause to be
carried out the construction of the public work or public improvement;
provided, that the Director of Public Works or the designated officer shall
employ, exclusively, for the performance of all manual labor thereon, laborers
and artisans whom the Village shall pay by the day or hour. All material of a
value of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) and upward to be used in the
construction of the public work or public improvement shall be purchased by
contract let to the lowest responsible bidder after advertising for bids,
unless the Board of Trustees shall previously authorize the letting of a
contract for such materials without advertising for bids by a vote of two-
thirds (2/3) of all the Trustees then holding office.
   B.   "Responsible bidder for construction contracts over ten thousand
dollars ($10,000.00)" means a bidder who meets all of the job specifications,
the following applicable criteria, and submits evidence of such compliance:
      1.   All applicable laws prerequisite to doing business in Illinois.
      2.   Evidence of compliance with:
         a.   Federal employer tax identification number or social security
number (for individuals).
         b.   Provision of section 2000(e) of chapter 21, title 42 of the
United States Code and Federal Executive Order no. 11246 as amended by
Executive Order no. 11375 (known as the equal opportunity employer provisions).
      3.   Certificates of insurance indicating the following coverages:
general liability, workers' compensation, completed operations, automobile,
hazardous occupation, and product liability.
      4.   Compliance with all provisions of the Illinois Prevailing Wage Act,
including wages, medical and hospitalization insurance, and retirement for
those trades covered in the Act.
      5.   The bidder and all bidder's subcontractors must participate in
active apprenticeship and training programs approved and registered with the
United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Apprenticeship and Training for
each of the trades of work contemplated under the awarded contract.
      6.   All contractors and subcontractors are required to turn in certified
payrolls as specified in Illinois Public Act 94-0515 and follow all provisions
of the Employee Classification Act, 820 Illinois Compiled Statutes 185/1 et
seq.
      7.   All bidders must provide three (3) projects of a similar nature as
being performed in the immediate past five (5) years with the name, address,
and telephone number of the contact person having knowledge of the project
along with three (3) references (name, address, and telephone number) with
knowledge of the integrity and business practices of the contractor. (Ord. 23-
2019, 2-26-2019)
CHAPTER 4
CEMETERIES
SECTION:
8-4-1: Definition
8-4-2: Boundaries
8-4-3: Extension
8-4-4: Burials
8-4-5: Notice To Disinter
8-4-1: DEFINITION:
The word "cemetery" in this Chapter means a place for the burial of the bodies
of deceased persons, and the words "existing cemetery" mean a cemetery which on
January 1, 1919 had been dedicated and was on said date in actual use as a
place for the burial of the dead, whether such dedication be by plat, deed,
ordinance or by prescriptive right. (1976 Code § 11.02; amd. 1981 Code)
8-4-2: BOUNDARIES:
The boundaries of any existing cemetery within the Village and within one-half
(1/2) mile of the Village shall, for the purpose of this Chapter be the
enclosure of such cemetery on January 1, 1981, and the boundaries of such
existing cemetery as was not so enclosed on January 1, 1981 shall be the same
as such cemetery appeared of record on January 1, 1981, in plats, ordinances,
deeds or other evidences showing, or tending to show, the lawful establishment
and location of such cemetery. (1976 Code § 11.02; amd. 1981 Code)
8-4-3: EXTENSION:
It shall be unlawful for any person to establish or maintain or to attempt to
establish or maintain within the corporate limits of the Village, or within
one-half (1/2) mile of the corporate limits of the Village, any cemetery not
established and maintained on January 1, 1981, nor shall any person extend or
enlarge any cemetery existing and established on January 1, 1981 within the
corporate limits of the Village or within one-half (1/2) mile of the corporate
limits of the Village. (1976 Code § 11.02; amd. 1981 Code)
8-4-4: BURIALS:
No person shall bury the body of any dead person within the Village or within
one mile of the corporate limits of the Village except in an existing cemetery.
(1976 Code § 11.02; amd. 1981 Code)
8-4-5: NOTICE TO DISINTER:
Upon notice in writing served by any officer of the Village upon any person
responsible for any burial which is illegal under this Chapter, or owning the
ground where such burial was made, to disinter the body illegally buried, it
shall be the duty of such person, within ten (10) days after the service of
such notice, to disinter and lawfully dispose of such body. (1976 Code § 11.02;
amd. 1981 Code)
CHAPTER 5
RAILROADS
SECTION:
8-5-1: Blocking Street Crossings
8-5-2: Switches
8-5-3: Sidings
8-5-4: Moving To And Fro
8-5-5: Speed Of Trains
8-5-6: Penalty
8-5-1: BLOCKING STREET CROSSINGS:
   A.   Prohibition: No railway company, railroad engineer, train conductor or
other person shall cause or allow any locomotive engine, car or cars, or train
of cars to stop in or remain upon any street or railroad crossing within the
Village for a longer period than ten (10) minutes at any one time, under a
penalty of a ten dollar ($10.00) fine for each and every consecutive minute in
excess of the hereinbefore mentioned ten (10) minutes' period that a locomotive
engine, car or cars or train of cars is or are allowed to remain upon any
street or railroad crossing; provided however, that in case a collision should
take place at any or either of the crossings aforesaid, reasonable time shall
be allowed to remove any such obstruction that may be caused thereby. (1976
Code § 39.01)
   B.   Clearing Crossing: Should any street or railroad crossing in the
Village be and remain occupied and obstructed in whole or in part by any
locomotive engine, train or railroad cars, or portion thereof, for and during a
period of ten (10) consecutive minutes, it is hereby made the duty of each and
every company or railroad owner, upon whose line of road such obstruction may
occur, its agents or employees, at the expiration of such ten (10) minutes
when, from any cause, the entire train cannot be propelled or removed to any
one side of any street occupied and obstructed as aforesaid, to cause such cars
as may be in or near said crossing to be uncoupled, and some one division of
the train, as thus made, removed from off the aforesaid street or railroad
crossing in such manner as to leave such street entirely free and unobstructed
and such train, when again coupled, shall be removed forthwith from off any
such crossing as aforesaid. (1976 Code § 39.02)
8-5-2: SWITCHES:
No frog, switch, rail or any part of a side track or turn shall be placed in or
across any portion of a public street without special permission from the
Village President and Board of Trustees; nor shall what is known as a "running
switch" be permitted along or across a public street. (1976 Code § 39.03)
8-5-3: SIDINGS:
No tracks, sidings, side tracks, switches or switch tracks shall be laid upon
the streets, alleys or public grounds of the Village without the permission of
the Village President and Board of Trustees being first had and obtained for
the laying of such tracks, sidings, side tracks, switches or switch tracks, and
the Village police are hereby authorized immediately to remove such tracks,
siding, side tracks, switches or switch tracks as may hereafter be laid in
violation of this Section. (1976 Code § 39.04)
8-5-4: MOVING TO AND FRO:
No train of a greater length than will reach from one street to another shall
be moved to and fro or for the purpose of transferring said train, or any part
of it, to another and opposite or adjoining track or tracks, in making up
trains, or distributing the same. (1976 Code § 39.05)
8-5-5: SPEED OF TRAINS:
It shall be unlawful for any railroad company conductor, engineer, agent or
other employee managing or controlling any locomotive, engine, car or train of
cars upon any railroad track to drive, run or propel the same, within the
limits of the Village, between County Line Road and Route 83 at a greater speed
than thirty (30) miles per hour. (Ord. 24, 1-8-1890; amd. by Motion, 1-25-1890;
1981 Code)
8-5-6: PENALTY:
Unless otherwise provided, any person, and all persons assisting, advising or
abetting the violation of any of the provisions of this Chapter, or who shall
fail to observe the provisions hereof, shall be fined not less than ten dollars
($10.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. (1976
Code § 39.06; amd. 7-8-1982)

8-6-8-8: Regulation of Waste Received from Other Jurisdictions

8-6-1: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
8-6-1-1: ENACTMENT:
Pursuant to the requirements of the Federal Clean Water Act and regulations
promulgated thereunder, the Illinois Environmental Protection Act of 1970, as
amended, and in accordance with Illinois Municipal Code: 65 ILCS 5/11-141-2:
Sec. 11-141-2, 65 ILCS 5/11-126-4: Sec. 11-126-4, 65 ILSC 5/11-126-4: Sec. 11-
141-7, and 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1: Sec.
1-2-1; this chapter, hereby known as Sewer Use and Pretreatment Ordinance, is
enacted by the board of trustees of the Village of Bensenville. (Ord. 4-2020,
1-28-2020)
8-6-1-2: PURPOSE AND POLICY:
This chapter sets forth uniform requirements for users of the publicly owned
treatment works for the Village of Bensenville, hereafter referred to
interchangeably as the village. This chapter provides for the use of public and
private sewers and drains, private sewage disposal, and authorizes the
installation and continuing of connections into the sewage works of the village
upon certain conditions, including permission thereof; providing for the
installation and maintenance of such connections and enforcements thereto;
regulating the use of municipal and private sewers and drains; individual
wastewater disposal, the installation, connection and disconnection of building
sewers, the discharge of water and waste in the public sewer system providing
for penalties for violation therefore; and providing for penalties for
violation thereof; and providing for termination of permits issued by the
village pursuant to the provisions hereof.
   This chapter enables the village to comply with all applicable state and
federal laws, including the Clean Water Act (33 United States Code § 1251 et
seq.) and the General Pretreatment Regulations of 40 CFR Part 403. Additional
objectives of this chapter are:
   A.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned
treatment works (POTW) that will interfere with its operation;
   B.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned
treatment works that will pass through the publicly owned treatment works,
inadequately treated, into receiving waters, or otherwise be incompatible with
the publicly owned treatment works;
   C.   To protect both publicly owned treatment works personnel who may be
affected by air, wastewater and bio-solids in the course of their employment
and the general public;
   D.   To promote reuse and recycling of industrial wastewater and bio-solids
from the publicly owned treatment works;
   E.   To enable the village to comply with its National Pollutant Discharge
Elimination System permit conditions, bio-solids use and disposal requirements,
and any other federal or state laws to which the publicly owned treatment works
is subject;
   F.   To provide for fees for the equitable distribution of the cost of
operation, maintenance, and improvement of the publicly owned treatment works;
   G.   To provide uniform requirements for food service establishments for the
control of grease discharge to the sanitary sewer system; and
   H.   To regulate private wastewater disposal systems.
   This chapter shall apply to all users of the publicly owned treatment works
and provides for the enforcement of general requirements for users. The chapter
authorizes the issuance of wastewater connection and discharge permits;
provides for monitoring, compliance, and enforcement activities; establishes
administrative review procedures; requires User reporting; and provides for the
setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the
programs established herein. The chapter authorizes the issuance of wastewater
discharge permits that do not allow the discharge of defined process waste
streams but continue to allow the discharge of domestic or sanitary wastewater.
(Ord. 4-2020, 1-28-2020)
8-6-1-3: ADMINISTRATION:
   A.   Except as otherwise provided herein, the pretreatment coordinator and/
or duly authorized agent(s) shall administer, implement, and enforce the
provisions of this chapter. Any powers granted to or duties imposed upon the
pretreatment coordinator and/or duly authorized agent(s) may be delegated by
the village or pretreatment coordinator to other village personnel or other
duly authorized agent(s) of the village.
   B.   It shall be the duty of employees of the police, building, engineering,
street, and water departments to give vigilant aid to the department of public
works in the enforcement of this chapter and to this end they shall report all
violations thereof, which come to their knowledge, to the director of public
works (DPW). The employees of other municipal governments shall report all
violations of locations that have wastewater discharges to the POTW to the
director of public works which come to their knowledge. (Ord. 4-2020, 1-28-
2020)
8-6-1-4: JURISDICTION:
This chapter shall apply to the village and to persons outside the village who
are, by contract or agreement with the village, users of the village POTW.
(Ord. 4-2020, 1-28-2020)

8-6-1-6: DEFINITIONS:
Unless a provision explicitly states otherwise, the following terms and
phrases, as used in this chapter, shall have the meanings hereinafter
designated.
   ACT or THE ACT or CLEAN WATER ACT or FEDERAL ACT: Means the Federal Water
Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 U.S.C.
§ 1251 et seq.
   ACTION LEVEL: Means the concentration based numeric value that the grease
interceptor effluent, at the device's outlet tee and prior to mixing with any
other wastewater from the contributing establishment's property, that the FSE
is expected to achieve on a consistent or stipulated basis. The Action Level is
200 mg/l.
   AMALGAM PROCESS WASTEWATER: Means any wastewater generated and discharged by
a dental discharger through the practice of dentistry that may contain dental
amalgam.
   AMALGAM SEPARATOR: Means a collection device designed to capture and remove
dental amalgam from the amalgam process wastewater of a dental facility.
   AGENCY: Means the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency.
   APPROVAL AUTHORITY: Means the Regional Administrator of Region V of USEPA,
until such time that the State of Illinois has a USEPA approved pretreatment
program.
   AUTHORIZED REPRESENTATIVE OF THE USER: Means
      1.   If the user is a corporation:
         a.   By a responsible corporate officer - the president, secretary,
treasurer, or a vice-president of the corporation in charge of a principal
business function, or any other Person who performs similar policy or decision-
making functions for the corporation; or
         b.   The manager of one or more manufacturing, production, or
operation facilities provided the manager is authorized to make management
decisions that govern the operation of the regulated facility including having
the explicit or implicit duty of making major capital investment
